[McLaughlin]: Hello, my name is Melanie McLaughlin and Austin street and men for mass Thank you Councilors for hearing us tonight and.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you to Trish and to the parents who are really organizing a lot of this.

[McLaughlin]: It's great to see the energy.

[McLaughlin]: And as we think about our children and young adults in this community, I have to say that you can tell immediately people who have experience with people with disabilities, because they know how to talk to them, they know how to

[McLaughlin]: interact with them and they appreciate and see them as human beings.

[McLaughlin]: And Councilor Leming and school committee member Olapade did that recently at the library event.

[McLaughlin]: It was really wonderful to see them playing Uno with a number of our children and getting involved.

[McLaughlin]: And I'll tell you, I have a seven, I can't believe she's 17, I have a 17 year old daughter with Down syndrome, excuse my hoarseness, I have a cold, with Down syndrome, who is also legally blind and,

[McLaughlin]: You know, she's the best thing that ever happened to us she's taught us so much about compassion and kindness and so many things, and I think when other people get to meet people with disabilities, they learn that lesson themselves, and not that our kids are here to teach the rest of us about humanity but that's just who they are and it is what they do.

[McLaughlin]: And, you know, a community that misses out on that misses out on quite a lot.

[McLaughlin]: and I wouldn't change anything.

[McLaughlin]: And I do have to say though, in terms of adaptive and other programming, I just wanna put a bug in everybody's ear too.

[McLaughlin]: As you're thinking about inclusion, adaptive is great and we want, that's the other thing is you have to have programs with support, right?

[McLaughlin]: It's not just, oh yeah, you're all welcome here, which has often been the case, which is really nice, it's nice to be welcome.

[McLaughlin]: But if you're welcome and there's no support and then it doesn't go well, then you're really not welcome and it's setting up our kids for failure.

[McLaughlin]: So having the support to make sure that it's actually a welcoming community and an inclusive community, not just, you know, in, in theory only because it takes support it takes skill, and not from parents from people who have skill you know that been experience over the time where in the interaction with parents around skill I remember, I remember our daughter having a swim lessons in the,

[McLaughlin]: And the schools and young teenagers are working with our kids a lot and they're not really getting trained to be able to have that experience and seeing my daughter in the pool and just teaching something as simple as first then right first let's do the swimming the lab, then you'll get to go, you know, do whatever it's a really simple lesson, but if you don't know it you don't know it and so just being able to learn the basics is really important.

[McLaughlin]: And as we think about the training and being able to see not just recreation, being able to see our children, again, use the library, use the coffee shops, feel welcome, feel included, and feel part of.

[McLaughlin]: I mean, I can't say enough about Amici's and West Medford.

[McLaughlin]: They are the most inclusive business I've experienced in Medford.

[McLaughlin]: Mario and his team make us feel right at home, make Gracie feel right at home.

[McLaughlin]: And Amici means friend.

[McLaughlin]: And he was teaching Gracie that the other day and I thought that was really beautiful.

[McLaughlin]: So I hope that you guys get the chance to meet all these wonderful young adults and people in our community, beyond just the schools and the students and you know the schools are required by law just to provide all of the extracurricular activities that any other student is entitled to.

[McLaughlin]: to every student.

[McLaughlin]: And so again, you know, we did ask when I was on the school committee to include a statement that if you need accommodations for any of these experiences please contact and we had a specific contact around what accommodations needed to be available and how parents could, you know, reach out and let folks know that they need accommodations.

[McLaughlin]: Some parents don't even want to do that because it feels like a lot for them.

[McLaughlin]: So it's important to continue to reach out as well.

[McLaughlin]: But that's something to consider, that how can we collaborate to make sure that the accommodations are helpful and real.

[McLaughlin]: And I have to say this, if you've never been to a dance with people with disabilities, you're really missing out because they really dance like nobody's watching.

[McLaughlin]: So thank you very much.

[McLaughlin]: Yeah, thank you.

[McLaughlin]: Melanie McLaughlin, Alston Street, Medford Moss.

[McLaughlin]: Rick McLaughlin, 87 West Street.

[McLaughlin]: I'm compelled to speak with you today for three reasons.

[McLaughlin]: So I'm not gonna, I'll just say yes to what they've said.

[McLaughlin]: The second reason is I'm the son of a career music educator, taught music in public schools for 40 years.

[McLaughlin]: And he told me in the 1970s that this would happen.

[McLaughlin]: I'm going to tell you about that in a second.

[McLaughlin]: The third reason is because as a professional musician myself and professor at the most influential school of music in the world, I've seen the power of music on four continents, both as a performer and as a clinician.

[McLaughlin]: So my dad, he taught music in public schools for 40 years.

[McLaughlin]: I remember in the 1970s, he told me that one day what would happen is the school committee or principals or whoever was actually managing money would cut the music program enough

[McLaughlin]: that it just, it wouldn't cut it completely, just enough to let it die, which is what is happening.

[McLaughlin]: You say that you're going to still support the arts, that's not true.

[McLaughlin]: The impact that other people have already discussed, you should take to heart because it's very important.

[McLaughlin]: But there's another element that's very important, which is the mission of the Medford Public Schools is to provide a supportive and effective educational environment that helps students successfully meet their individualized goals.

[McLaughlin]: This will no longer be true when you cut Ms.

[McLaughlin]: Ferrello's position.

[McLaughlin]: By cutting her position, you will make it so that

[McLaughlin]: Future students do not sign up for music.

[McLaughlin]: A previous student spoke about how it's virtually impossible to do it anyway because of the ways that the scheduling conflicts prevent them from actually taking these courses.

[McLaughlin]: M-Y-E-L-I-N, myelin.

[McLaughlin]: That is the aspect of the brain, the neurological neuron wrapping that actually makes your brain process information more effectively and more quickly.

[McLaughlin]: None of the things that you teach in school, none of the things Mr. Rousseau referred to earlier, English, math, science, history, I can't remember what the rest was on his list, none of those things actually improve or increase brain processing speed

[McLaughlin]: The only thing that does is music.

[McLaughlin]: By cutting Miss Rello's position, you no longer support the arts.

[McLaughlin]: You also no longer support the mission of the school because you no longer support the brain health of the students who go here.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: the different subcommittees that are going to exist for the upcoming term.

[McLaughlin]: So I think again, the form was super helpful.

[McLaughlin]: I just think it was kind of ad hoc and, you know, put together and I don't think the committee

[McLaughlin]: collectively decided how that process was going to work.

[McLaughlin]: And I think we need to, um, especially when we're no longer here and other people are doing it and they need to have a basis for how it needs to be done.

[McLaughlin]: So, um, I would like us to consider that there needs to be a process for the subcommittees and what that process for the creation of subcommittees and identification of members of subcommittees and what that process should look like.

[McLaughlin]: you know, really overheated and other students that populations that really need to be considered.

[McLaughlin]: I would agree in some of the cases.

[McLaughlin]: I don't know that that's all.

[McLaughlin]: And so also there's individual health care plans that families can help create and that school

[McLaughlin]: educators know about.

[McLaughlin]: And so that should be something that families can know about and can be considered as part of this as well, because I think it's really critical.

[McLaughlin]: Because some of the nursing staff may or may not know some of the students, depending on their conditions.

[McLaughlin]: And I'm thinking particularly of a student maybe that doesn't communicate with words, but is getting overheated.

[McLaughlin]: And it's not typically in the nurse's office.

[McLaughlin]: In out of district residential placements, the students do come home during school vacations and on some occasions.

[McLaughlin]: And when that would occur, the student,

[McLaughlin]: had no opportunity in the community really to be engaged and involved, and was not able to really be part of the community and in the schools and mom in particular shared that story with us, the family was.

[McLaughlin]: from Brazil initially and had emigrated here.

[McLaughlin]: And mom was a single mom and had done a tremendous job and had shared that at a leadership, disability leadership program that we were in and they were Medford.

[McLaughlin]: The little girl passed away when she was 15.

[McLaughlin]: Her name is Emily Oliveira.

[McLaughlin]: She's actually in the Oakland Park Cemetery right next to Crystal and her picture's there.

[McLaughlin]: And I think she deserves to be remembered in particular around this inclusive playground

[McLaughlin]: and in particular around the swings.

[McLaughlin]: Mom really wanted a swing that was accessible for her wheelchair.

[McLaughlin]: And I would like some commemoration to Emily and her mom for what I feel like the community should have done for them a long time ago.

[McLaughlin]: And I know that mom would be really thrilled to see something like that for Emily.

[McLaughlin]: A whole wall.

[McLaughlin]: Yeah, I think that I wanna weigh in on some of that just in terms of, yeah, I think the survey, two things, I think we're having two conversations.

[McLaughlin]: If we're having another survey and we wanna compare it to the base data that we have now, we need to compare apples to apples in terms of a survey, just in terms of statistics and data.

[McLaughlin]: However, if we think that the survey that we're talking about, the panoramic survey is actually much more expansive

[McLaughlin]: and at the same time, much more detailed, then there's a different conversation about, okay, maybe we need the panoramic survey, we do that, and then we have a comparison to that as apples to apples for next year.

[McLaughlin]: So this year we do the panoramic survey and then apples to apples for next year, because the panoramic survey, if it's being used by other districts, then we compare, we have some basis of comparison.

[McLaughlin]: This homemade, if you will, survey,

[McLaughlin]: for our district only is not going to offer any basis of comparison to another district because it's for this district only.

[McLaughlin]: That said, there are outliers in this data and the outliers to me are the, you know, certainly about the, you know, the student being able to have some discussion around, you know, their needs and what have you, but, you know, the two of the bigger outliers to me and clearly to the data

[McLaughlin]: are on the, you know, students in this school are teased or picked on about their real or perceived sexual orientation.

[McLaughlin]: 32% agree with that, 50% don't.

[McLaughlin]: Students at the school are teased or picked on about their physical or intellectual disability.

[McLaughlin]: 34% agree about that, 44% don't.

[McLaughlin]: And so these are things that are, you know, even in the standard sort of data set at our school, I agree, we want those to be 40%, but clearly in an overall aggregate picture,

[McLaughlin]: we can see that we have some cultural and climate issues around competency, cultural competency, frankly, both in terms of ableism and sexism and other isms, I'm sure.

[McLaughlin]: So I think that that clearly shows us that there's a focus, but I guess that said, the real question here is what are we looking for?

[McLaughlin]: Are we looking to use base data here and have a comparison

[McLaughlin]: you know, mid-year or are we looking to let's have a standard that other districts are using in the state?

[McLaughlin]: And I think that's the difference between the question.

[McLaughlin]: And I don't know if that's an agenda item for next time or if there needs to be a motion for that or what, but I think we're trying to answer two different questions in terms of data.

[McLaughlin]: And I think we have to be very clear about what it is we want.

[McLaughlin]: So I guess to that end, I would make a motion for us to use a panoramic survey as a standard survey for the one coming out in, if it's, you know, at the end of January or what have you, and we'll do our best to make some comparison to this, but with the idea that the following year we'll use the same survey, so.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you for the

[McLaughlin]: report in fair time tonight.

[McLaughlin]: I had some questions specific to the, I mean, I think we've been talking about the equity issue for some time.

[McLaughlin]: And I do agree with my colleague around having some of the narrative of the data, some sort of qualitative narrative of the quantitative data would be really helpful for the community as well.

[McLaughlin]: in understanding the disparity.

[McLaughlin]: There's obviously a stark disparity in some of the numbers, especially based at the elementary level.

[McLaughlin]: And so I think people would wanna know why.

[McLaughlin]: And then also I think it sort of can help dispel some of the notions that some schools are better than others or what have you, which is not the case.

[McLaughlin]: And so really being able to help folks understand that I think would be really helpful

[McLaughlin]: And it would also be helpful for us as we're thinking about what the budgeting priorities are across the district and what things look like in terms of if we're really talking about equity as a priority.

[McLaughlin]: As we've said many times before, equity is not that everybody gets the same, it's that everybody gets what they need.

[McLaughlin]: And so, with that in mind, really thinking about that.

[McLaughlin]: Regarding the instructional priorities, I'm wondering if there's any, I know there's high quality instructional development

[McLaughlin]: you know, data-informed decision-making you're talking about, is there any PD being offered around differentiation of materials or universal design for learning?

[McLaughlin]: Okay, so what I'm hearing you say is that that's part of all of the trainings, but nothing specific to differentiation or universal design.

[McLaughlin]: Okay.

[McLaughlin]: The weekly meetings at the grade level,

[McLaughlin]: That's the new schedule sort of, especially at the elementary.

[McLaughlin]: Are those meetings with all staff, teachers, all teaching staff, so general education and special education together, or are they segregated?

[McLaughlin]: Right.

[McLaughlin]: So it sounds like we have work to do there as well in terms of it.

[McLaughlin]: If we're really talking equity and we're really talking common planning time and we're really talking everybody together, then it sounds to me like we need to think about what a schedule looks like so that people are working together and being able to, we have expertise in the district around differentiation and universal design and all of the things that could be incorporated.

[McLaughlin]: But if they're not meeting together to be able to have some common

[McLaughlin]: basis and understanding of that.

[McLaughlin]: And thank you.

[McLaughlin]: And if there are student, may I follow up there to that?

[McLaughlin]: If there are students and staff for that matter that are experiencing symptoms of heat,

[McLaughlin]: illness, heat stroke, anything like that.

[McLaughlin]: What can be done?

[McLaughlin]: I know for myself, I went for a walk on Friday.

[McLaughlin]: I did not anticipate coming back in the afternoon.

[McLaughlin]: I came back in the afternoon for the walk.

[McLaughlin]: It was like a five mile walk halfway through the walk.

[McLaughlin]: I honestly didn't think I was gonna make it.

[McLaughlin]: And I started shivering, which is a clear sign that something's wrong if you're shivering in the 90 plus degree heat.

[McLaughlin]: So how are we sharing with families and staff and others how to recognize

[McLaughlin]: examples of heat exhaustion, heat stroke, referrals to nursing, like are we doing anything that can help remediate any of that?

[McLaughlin]: Sorry.

[McLaughlin]: So if there are issues like that, they can go to nursing, let staffing know, go to nursing and nursing should be able to help support our families.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: I think that when I'm looking at this bullying, so I get that conflict bullying, not bullying, which I want to talk about the flow chart as well that Peter had created around helping simplify this because I think that's part of the issue is that we need to have some visual clarity because this is a, I forget how, 16 page document.

[McLaughlin]: That can be a lot and a lot of folks are TLDR, but also a lot of folks are visual learners.

[McLaughlin]: We haven't addressed that piece either, which I want to address before this meeting is over.

[McLaughlin]: But this particularly suggests to me that a finding of bullying only occurs when there is students who are not considered to be equal in power.

[McLaughlin]: So when the incident is determined between two students who are not considered to be equal in power within the quality of problem.

[McLaughlin]: So what if the students are equal in power and one is bullying the other?

[McLaughlin]: How is that investigation

[McLaughlin]: And so we said earlier.

[McLaughlin]: Yeah, question.

[McLaughlin]: So how is that qualified if they are equal in power and there's a bullying?

[McLaughlin]: Mayor, Member McLaughlin.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: Since I sort of had brought up this with questions, I appreciate getting the floor back again.

[McLaughlin]: One is

[McLaughlin]: I can hear the nuance in this discussion, and I think it's important.

[McLaughlin]: And I would really ask also our colleagues, as a whole, if we're not using value statements around individuals doing their work, or whether they're degrading something, or that sort of language.

[McLaughlin]: I was at every policy

[McLaughlin]: subcommittee meeting with the exception of one.

[McLaughlin]: And some of this must have been the last conversation too, because I hadn't heard a lot of the argument around this, or I'll have to look back at the minutes because I don't recall a lot of the arguments or discussion around this.

[McLaughlin]: I think I can see both sides in terms of the power differential, but this is a very subjective thing, power differential.

[McLaughlin]: And it's like we had instances with our own family members who were very much being bullied.

[McLaughlin]: In this situation, there was a power differential.

[McLaughlin]: It was not seen necessarily by the principal because the principal very likely doesn't understand nuances of middle school power dynamics.

[McLaughlin]: And they're very subtle and can be relational as opposed to physical.

[McLaughlin]: They can be all sorts of things.

[McLaughlin]: So I think that's why there's such clarity and why and how you find a

[McLaughlin]: finding of bullying, and my concern my main concern about this which I think power differentials are an issue, and very much very often are the instances but not only and also it leaves to somebody discretion to determine whether there's a power differential as opposed to the other requirements that are part of state law which I think

[McLaughlin]: is critical.

[McLaughlin]: So I'm a little, I'm a little conflicted around this, which is why I'm having or asking that this be thought out a little bit more to do the chair to member Graham's point I understand what you're saying about wanting to really clarify the conflict bullying and not bullying because believe me, ours was ruled conflict and it, you know,

[McLaughlin]: And many others have been, as I've known, and I think would qualify under this, but it's because it leaves it so subjective to what this is.

[McLaughlin]: And I think this even makes it more subjective, frankly, around the power differential.

[McLaughlin]: So I don't know how to fix this, and I don't know if it's a state fix or what it is, but I think that maybe there's some middle ground, there's some opportunity for some rewarding or negotiation or something here, because

[McLaughlin]: I hear both sides of the argument and it's concerning for me, especially around, you know, and it still didn't answer the question is what happens when, you know, two people are in a situation and one is bullying the other, and it's not seen as a power differential, because for whatever reason, because maybe there's not a known power differential there.

[McLaughlin]: internally it's a power differential because somebody else is scared and the other one's not, but how does that determine?

[McLaughlin]: I mean, it's such nuance, it's, you know, emotions.

[McLaughlin]: How do you know internally whether there's a power differential or not?

[McLaughlin]: Or, you know, but for all appearances sake, they're both on the football team, you know, one's the quarterback, one's the linebacker, I don't know.

[McLaughlin]: And what, you know, they seem to be equals, they're of the same height, weight, abilities, you know, all of those things, but clearly one is, you know, bullying and,

[McLaughlin]: the other is not, how do you know that there's a power, you know, what do you do if there's not a power differential, yet there is bullying, which I think is why there's that clarification under the definition.

[McLaughlin]: So I hear two competing things here.

[McLaughlin]: Identifying and the difference of conflict bullying and not bullying or conflict, which I think is a tricky bit for everybody.

[McLaughlin]: And then the other is being consistent with our definition.

[McLaughlin]: and really clarifying what that is of bullying and making sure that we're aligning with what the state standard is.

[McLaughlin]: And then the third is that bullying often occurs when there's a power differential.

[McLaughlin]: And I'm not sure I know the solution, but I do think that just sort of plowing through or, you know, not plowing through, but saying, well, the subcommittee decided on this and this is why is not helpful because all of this committee, we're a committee of seven that needs to decide this material.

[McLaughlin]: So that's why we're having the discussion.

[McLaughlin]: Can we make any suggestions about how to support some language here?

[McLaughlin]: Howard has his hand up too, excuse me.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: And this is- Point of information?

[McLaughlin]: Or actually, point of clarification though, through the member or so, if I may, through the chair.

[McLaughlin]: May I, Member Ruseau?

[McLaughlin]: I'm not sure if Chair stepped away.

[McLaughlin]: We all have.

[McLaughlin]: I've been waiting a little bit, a little while.

[McLaughlin]: which is why I think maybe you can't see me but I wanted to ask as well so there's a few things when I first came on to the school committee, the budget process was very different than it is now and I know that we had a director of finance in the interim, that sort of change things and some of the recommendations

[McLaughlin]: on recommendations from this committee.

[McLaughlin]: In the past, just so for folks who are listening or in the audience or watching online, in the past, what would happen is department heads would come before the committee, would sort of describe what happened in their, what happens in their department, would break down what their department did and what they were proposing was needed in the future.

[McLaughlin]: And that process was sort of eliminated in this last iteration.

[McLaughlin]: And it became more of a sort of global look at it at a larger number.

[McLaughlin]: I frankly liked

[McLaughlin]: the transparency that occurred when department heads were able to come up and we were able to ask them about what was needed and how we were able to get to certain numbers.

[McLaughlin]: I know that the process was longer as a result of that, but personally, I preferred that.

[McLaughlin]: I felt like it was more, for me, it helped me better understand the budget and where money was coming and going.

[McLaughlin]: And we were also able to really understand what each school had.

[McLaughlin]: So how many adjustment Councilors were at X school, how many,

[McLaughlin]: you know, BCBAs, we're at Wise School, we were able to sort of see equity across the district or inequity across the district and how it might be able to be addressed.

[McLaughlin]: And in this iteration, I'm not finding that as much.

[McLaughlin]: So I just want to mention that to my colleagues here and to the audience as well, because I think that we always have the opportunity to change the process.

[McLaughlin]: And I think the more transparent and simplified the process can be, as much as one can do with a, you know, $70-$80 million budget, the better it is.

[McLaughlin]: I have worked on multi-million dollar budgets in my professional life, and it has been a much different process and one much more similar to what we had seen earlier with sort of department by department, subtotal by subtotal.

[McLaughlin]: which for me was particularly helpful.

[McLaughlin]: Another real concern I have about this budget is we're talking SEL, we're talking post-pandemic relief, we're talking ARPA and ESSER.

[McLaughlin]: And, you know, I haven't really heard a lot of discussion about our underrepresented subgroups and the increased need of our underrepresented subgroups, particularly we know we have a mental health crisis happening right now, how we're just how we're, you know, thinking about that for our student population, how we're thinking about we just recently to my

[McLaughlin]: relief passed a resolution, ensuring non discrimination and inclusion and non exclusion from all activities that are school based before school, during school and after school, and yet I continue to hear from families, and I am concerned about particularly summer programming.

[McLaughlin]: And what we're doing around summer programming, for example, the summer fun camp, which has historically been, you know, one or two general education teachers and a lot of high school students.

[McLaughlin]: More recently, through a lot of work from community members, we were able to get increased services provided there for some students with higher needs, students with disabilities, other students.

[McLaughlin]: so that they could access that program.

[McLaughlin]: That doesn't seem clear to me as to whether that's happening this summer, or whether that's happening with any of our summer programming or enrichment programming or after school programming, or any of our programming and I don't know, a lot of times when we asked that question we're told this step that people aren't available, that it's hard difficult to hire folks but if we don't even have them.

[McLaughlin]: allocated in a budget, or if we're not talking about how they are allocated in the budget, if they are, whether it's through additional special education funding for grants that, again, we don't see on this particular budget sheet, which can be substantive in their money, the IDEA funds, other funds, not knowing where that money is going is really tricky for me, and understanding how that gets teased out is really tricky for me.

[McLaughlin]: And also, I think we talked in the last meeting or the meeting prior,

[McLaughlin]: specifically about the revolving accounts and what kind of income they generate.

[McLaughlin]: So for example, if the, and this is just an example, I don't have these numbers for real, but if, for example, the summer fund program, which is a summer camp for students in the Medford community that is housed in one of our schools, if for example that, and it's tuition driven,

[McLaughlin]: If, for example, that program made a profit of say, I don't know $40,000 I don't know that it does but say for example it made a profit of $40,000 yet was unable to accommodate individuals who had additional needs for any number of reasons because budget money wasn't allocated because what have you.

[McLaughlin]: That's not meeting the requirement of reasonable accommodations, for example, and how are we really considering that, particularly when we're talking about SEL for those who folks who don't understand the acronym I would just share it social emotional learning and the importance of belonging, being part of one's community and feeling that and also recruitment of skills so that you start in September.

[McLaughlin]: with the same skills that you had and regression, preventing regression of skills so that you don't go backwards over the summer, particularly for our more marginalized subgroups.

[McLaughlin]: to just share that part of the superintendent evaluation process should be happening throughout the year, right?

[McLaughlin]: I mean we're all hearing from constituents as school committee members about what

[McLaughlin]: their experiences are in the district what they would like to see changed or better or improved what they think is working, you know how things are sort of happening so we're seeing that throughout the year we definitely have public participation throughout the year as well.

[McLaughlin]: I think it's a longer conversation for the entire committee to have around, you know how and in what way.

[McLaughlin]: there'd be public participation in superintendent evaluation and also looking at what other districts are doing and what the protocol is and sort of all of those things.

[McLaughlin]: And because it can also, as you can imagine, the people that show up might be the squeaky wheels and the people that don't might not be.

[McLaughlin]: So there sort of has to be a process that we all agree is equitable and is one that is consistent and one that the MASC, which is the Mass Association of School Committees,

[McLaughlin]: and the MASS, which is the Mass Association of School Superintendents, would surely offer advice and let us know best practices around doing that as well.

[McLaughlin]: So I think that there's always opportunity for feedback.

[McLaughlin]: So I hope that you guys are reaching out to us to let us know.

[McLaughlin]: And also, I know that the superintendent has been receptive as well in terms of people reaching out to her.

[McLaughlin]: So I would encourage that too.

[McLaughlin]: And that's part of the building relationships that we should all be working on in terms of the family and community engagement.

[McLaughlin]: So I just I just sort of wanted to mention that as well.

[McLaughlin]: Absolutely.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: Yep, it is as part of the data that's that's if I may member pays I'm sorry.

[McLaughlin]: Sure.

[McLaughlin]: Absolutely, that's why we're going with a rubric.

[McLaughlin]: So thank you, you're absolutely right.

[McLaughlin]: It's shared with all the members across the board, same rubric.

[McLaughlin]: We're all evaluating based on the items we agreed to evaluate based on the superintendent's goal.

[McLaughlin]: So yes, that's what I was going to propose is that that's exactly at that if the event is wheelchair accessible.

[McLaughlin]: quote unquote grandfathered based on the status of the building.

[McLaughlin]: And I know that we waived the reading, but they are required under several of the laws that are noted in the motion.

[McLaughlin]: including Title IX, Section 504 Rehabilitation Act, IDEA, I mean, Title I of the Americans with Disabilities Act and Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act.

[McLaughlin]: Aye.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: the notice.

[McLaughlin]: This is a meeting of the Special Education Behavioral Health Subcommittee.

[McLaughlin]: I am the chair of the subcommittee along with members Rousseau and Mustone.

[McLaughlin]: So thank you all for coming.

[McLaughlin]: This meeting is, I'm just gonna read the notice.

[McLaughlin]: Please be advised that on Wednesday, May 3rd from five to 6 p.m.

[McLaughlin]: there's a special education subcommittee meeting, special education behavioral health subcommittee meeting to be held through remote participation via Zoom.

[McLaughlin]: The purpose of the subcommittee meeting will be to review and develop a non-discrimination slash inclusion statement for Medford Public Schools outreach slash information.

[McLaughlin]: The meeting can be viewed through Medford Community Media on Comcast Channel 15 and Verizon Channel 45 at 5 p.m.

[McLaughlin]: Since the meeting will be held remotely, participants can log in or call in by using the following link or call-in number.

[McLaughlin]: The link is mps02155-org.zoom.us.

[McLaughlin]: Actually, you can see it on the website if you need to go there, which you would if you're going on Zoom.

[McLaughlin]: and then the call in is 929-205-6099.

[McLaughlin]: Those submitting questions or comments need to include the following information.

[McLaughlin]: Comments or questions can be submitted during the meeting by emailing Melanie McLachlan, M-E-L-A-N-I-E-M-C-L-M-L-A-N-I-E.

[McLaughlin]: at medford.k12.ma.us, and those submitting questions or comments must include the following information.

[McLaughlin]: First and last name, Medford Street address, and your question or comment.

[McLaughlin]: So again, thank you all for coming.

[McLaughlin]: You just said she had a visitor.

[McLaughlin]: That's okay.

[McLaughlin]: That's okay.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: Member Mustone.

[McLaughlin]: Member McLaughlin here.

[McLaughlin]: Member Ruseau present.

[McLaughlin]: Great, thank you.

[McLaughlin]: So again, this is the purpose is to discuss an inclusion slash equity statement slash accommodation statement for Medford Public Schools.

[McLaughlin]: So I'm actually going to share my screen.

[McLaughlin]: I will send this to this document to

[McLaughlin]: the superintendent's office, Markey, after the meeting to share if needed, but I'll share my screen with folks as well.

[McLaughlin]: I did share it with committee members, with member Bowen, I mean, with Director of Pupil Services, Joan Bowen and Dr. Edouard-Vincent.

[McLaughlin]: So this is a document that sort of helps outline some of the discussion that I'd like to use.

[McLaughlin]: So this is just some research done on some differences in non-discrimination statement versus inclusion statement.

[McLaughlin]: So first of all, I wanna ground us in the work that we're doing right now.

[McLaughlin]: So based on the Medford Public Schools strategic plan,

[McLaughlin]: which has been approved.

[McLaughlin]: This is the E in the ACES acronym that Dr. Edouard-Vincent uses in terms of the strategic plan.

[McLaughlin]: And there's a link to that.

[McLaughlin]: It's also available on our website.

[McLaughlin]: And in there, within that, there's just a couple of statements that I think are relevant to the meeting today, which are

[McLaughlin]: You know prioritize systems that support a shared vision for disability awareness anti racism anti bias and cultural proficiency across the district.

[McLaughlin]: and provide equal access to academic support and enrichment, so I really want to ground us in that part of the strategic plan, which is where we're really feeling like.

[McLaughlin]: This statement applies and so folks may know that anybody receiving federal funds, of which most public schools do.

[McLaughlin]: they're required to have what's called a non-discrimination clause in their documentation on their website.

[McLaughlin]: It's supposed to be pretty easy to find, very straightforward.

[McLaughlin]: Ours is not particularly easy to find, and we can talk more about that shortly.

[McLaughlin]: But, you know, I just spent a bit of time just putting in

[McLaughlin]: words like non-discrimination, disability, gender, sort of those things, and it didn't readily come up.

[McLaughlin]: There is a statement from the superintendent on the homepage that talks a little bit about it, but it's not an actual non-discrimination clause.

[McLaughlin]: There are some, both in our policy, school committee policy statement and on some of the

[McLaughlin]: the ADA requirements on the website.

[McLaughlin]: But again, I definitely think it could be more prominent.

[McLaughlin]: But in any case, the non-discrimination clause is required, and it's, you know, what you typically see, people are probably really familiar with it, meant for public schools or your employment or any other place does not discriminate on the basis of, you know, so on and so forth.

[McLaughlin]: And

[McLaughlin]: The definition of non-discrimination is the practice of treating people, companies, countries, et cetera, and the same as others in order to be fair.

[McLaughlin]: And then I just wanted to share the definition of inclusion because I don't necessarily think that a non-discrimination statement or clause is also an inclusion clause.

[McLaughlin]: A well-written one should be, but that's not always the case.

[McLaughlin]: And so inclusion by definition is, and again this definition is from, you know, the CDC among others but they, I believe, took it from some of the laws and IDA what have you.

[McLaughlin]: But it's that all children regardless of ability or disability.

[McLaughlin]: have the right to be respected and appreciated as valuable members of the school community, fully participate in all school activities, and interact with peers of all ability levels with opportunities to develop friendships.

[McLaughlin]: So that's a little bit different than non-discrimination.

[McLaughlin]: And I'd like to say it's more strength-based, frankly.

[McLaughlin]: I think it's nice.

[McLaughlin]: It doesn't sort of have that, you know, some of the negative language that sometimes people see in the non-discrimination around

[McLaughlin]: There's some articles that I've referenced in here that folks can link to and check out if they want to just around the differences between the two.

[McLaughlin]: I do want to share an example from the community of one example of an inclusion form, if you will.

[McLaughlin]: And this was something that the Medford Special Education Parent Advisory Council and others, community members, worked with the Medford Recreation Department to include on all of their documentation.

[McLaughlin]: So it's a good example of something within the community.

[McLaughlin]: And so on all Medford Recreation

[McLaughlin]: notices, notification, what have you, they have the statement you see here for participants who wish to request special accommodations for program, please fill out our inclusion services request form.

[McLaughlin]: and please submit the form to, and you have the email here to submit the form to.

[McLaughlin]: In a minute, if folks want, I can click on that hyperlink and we can look at an example of the inclusion services request form.

[McLaughlin]: Here are some references to the conversation that I'm having now and sort of the origin of some of the conversation and the requirements for non-discrimination, but also some of them that expand to

[McLaughlin]: inclusion.

[McLaughlin]: And again, I'm not a lawyer, I'm not gonna get into the legal aspects, but under section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act and ADA, particularly in IDA as well, there are requirements to be inclusive of all persons, including students with disabilities, of course.

[McLaughlin]: Here's some resources I shared with you guys.

[McLaughlin]: The first is just an article written by a professor that I thought was pretty interesting on how she makes her syllabus more inclusive and the way that it's evolved over time.

[McLaughlin]: And I thought that was sort of interesting, particularly having studied inclusive education at the Harvard Graduate School of Education and working with Professor Hare there and him often talking about ways that we're actually

[McLaughlin]: considering being inclusive and the ways that, you know, he would often let people know they can stand up and stretch if they need to.

[McLaughlin]: They can sort of, he always made us use a microphone to make sure everyone could hear.

[McLaughlin]: There were just little different things that, ways to be inclusive beyond, you know, some of the standard

[McLaughlin]: quote unquote accommodations.

[McLaughlin]: The Every Student Initiative, I think, is something that you guys, you know, might want to take a look at.

[McLaughlin]: The link says ensure every student has access to high quality learning, but it's not just that.

[McLaughlin]: It's also about life of the school, enrichment activities, athletics, and so, you know, essentially the 504 Rehabilitation Act, ADA, and

[McLaughlin]: IDEA all apply to the life of the school.

[McLaughlin]: So it's not just the academic day, it is the life of the school.

[McLaughlin]: So any activities that students participate in as a school-based activity, these can include volunteer activities, these can include enrichment activities from outside organizations, what have you.

[McLaughlin]: But if they're the life of the school,

[McLaughlin]: meaning they're attached to the school, everyone in the school has been invited, they're in the school building, not necessarily have to be in the school building, but those sorts of things apply under ADA 504 and IDEA.

[McLaughlin]: So I'm happy to go back to some of these documents if folks want to look at them for a second, but I just wanted to share that the purpose really is for us to look at

[McLaughlin]: a sample inclusion statement or accommodation statement.

[McLaughlin]: Some people call it accommodation statements.

[McLaughlin]: It's interesting because when you look at inclusion statements these days, what's coming up a lot is DEI, DEI statements, which are also really interesting and some people refer to

[McLaughlin]: disability in their DEI statements and some people don't.

[McLaughlin]: Some people it's strictly anti-racism, which is another conversation that folks have because we all know disability is part of diversity as is culture and language and race and lots of things.

[McLaughlin]: But that was interesting in the search, but we did find some good examples.

[McLaughlin]: So I sort of wanted to give you guys that as like a starting point.

[McLaughlin]: So here's an example.

[McLaughlin]: I think this might have been either from Harvard or from.

[McLaughlin]: University of Virginia, but I can reference it if we need to.

[McLaughlin]: So we value inclusion and access for all participants and are pleased to provide reasonable accommodations for this activity slash event.

[McLaughlin]: Please contact.

[McLaughlin]: And you know, sensibly, this school committee or.

[McLaughlin]: the superintendent will have to clarify, would have to decide who a contact would be.

[McLaughlin]: It could be potentially an assistant principal, it could be the 504 coordinator, it could be director of pupil services.

[McLaughlin]: Please contact so-and-so to make a reasonable accommodation request, and then a date for a request to be submitted, and then noting that the event is accessible.

[McLaughlin]: Another organization said they recommend using an accommodation statement and publicity materials on all documents to let individuals know how to request accommodations for your event or program if needed, but also that it's accessible, like this event is wheelchair accessible or any of the other accessibility standards that we need to know.

[McLaughlin]: So I'm going to stop there for a second.

[McLaughlin]: I want to just show you guys a little bit more further down about

[McLaughlin]: sort of some of the things that we can look at.

[McLaughlin]: So we're going to look at some examples from Medford Public Schools about what's currently on our website and otherwise, and then some examples from other school districts about what's on their website, and then hopefully have a more robust conversation as well.

[McLaughlin]: But I just want to stop right there for a minute and let my colleagues and others take a breath and see if there are any questions or comments so far.

[McLaughlin]: Well, I would defer to Joan on that, but I would say yes, anything that is the life of the school.

[McLaughlin]: So if they're using school facilities, if it's including all school, all non-disabled students, if there are opportunities for that, then yes, but I want to ask the director of pupil services for perspective.

[McLaughlin]: And each building has a 504 coordinator?

[McLaughlin]: Yes.

[McLaughlin]: Okay, thank you.

[McLaughlin]: I think that's a good question.

[McLaughlin]: And that's something that I really want the group to discuss.

[McLaughlin]: So I think, so not only obviously the enrichment activities, the life of the schools, but obviously this applies to field trips, this applies to all things.

[McLaughlin]: And that is a big reason that we wanted to have this meeting today is because it is the fact that a lot of parents don't know that students are entitled to accommodations for life of the school.

[McLaughlin]: And frankly, there are a lot of staff members that might not understand that as well.

[McLaughlin]: And so I think it's important that this information goes out to you know any information that is that is a life of the school event so if it's an email going out from the principals about a school based activity if it's a potentially.

[McLaughlin]: a field trip form, anything, you know, similar to a nondiscrimination.

[McLaughlin]: So, one of the suggestions I had is to include the nondiscrimination statement on documentation and with an additional, you know, sentence or two around, you know, if your student requires accommodations, right, what you can do.

[McLaughlin]: Because really, we're supposed to be doing this.

[McLaughlin]: This is not like, you know,

[McLaughlin]: a favor we're asking.

[McLaughlin]: This is something that the district's really supposed to be doing.

[McLaughlin]: It's just that how is the information actually reaching families and getting to families and getting to staff and it's not quite clear how that is.

[McLaughlin]: I see Shanine has her hand up.

[McLaughlin]: So yes, Shanine, please.

[McLaughlin]: I think that there's some policy pieces here too that we need to talk about so you know definitely we might want to be, you know, to the other committee members, I would think that there are some things that we might recommend or refer to the rules policy and equity.

[McLaughlin]: subcommittee potentially with recommendations from the special behavioral health subcommittee and or a joint meeting around, you know, obviously you're absolutely right field trips are, you know, accommodations are required for field trips for students to meaningfully attend a field trip during the school day.

[McLaughlin]: I think the difference and again,

[McLaughlin]: Joan, I would defer to you, but I think that a little bit of the difference is the difference potentially in reasonable quote unquote accommodations, right?

[McLaughlin]: So reasonable accommodations, but if it's in the life of the school, there is a, you know, aspect of that.

[McLaughlin]: So, you know, there's been some historically some experience and I totally and fully understand that the PTOs are,

[McLaughlin]: volunteer organizations, right?

[McLaughlin]: And a lot of these events are fundraisers or afterschool enrichment opportunities or what have you.

[McLaughlin]: And if they're going to be held in the school and they're going to be offered to all students in the school, students with disabilities cannot be excluded under federal law, among other things.

[McLaughlin]: So the issue is not whether that's

[McLaughlin]: appropriate or not, in my opinion, the issue is how do we make sure that everybody's informed that students with disabilities and all students need to have access.

[McLaughlin]: And so if there are students that require additional accommodations, then we need to create a plan for them to be able to reach out to, again, Ms.

[McLaughlin]: Bowen has said, the ETL or building principal, which I think we should be really clear about.

[McLaughlin]: to discuss a reasonable accommodation.

[McLaughlin]: And we do, a lot of the reasonable accommodation requests have a date on them.

[McLaughlin]: So for example, with Medford Recreation, they have a reasonable accommodation request.

[McLaughlin]: If your student, if your child needs, you know, additional support to participate in this activity, please let us know by X date, you know, if say, so that we're not finding out, so that the school's not finding out the day before, you know, that there's a request for accommodations or something like that.

[McLaughlin]: fully.

[McLaughlin]: And again, it's a little bit different from an accommodation statement.

[McLaughlin]: So a non-discrimination statement is different.

[McLaughlin]: And you can see, you know, it talks about an integrated society, it talks about positive experiences, it talks about

[McLaughlin]: You know, other things, and it's the policy, not to discriminate and sort of what happens if you do discriminate or could happen if you do discriminate, but it doesn't talk about well what if you need accommodations, what if you need, you know, other things it doesn't sort of take that next step on our policy.

[McLaughlin]: But the other is the school lunch.

[McLaughlin]: There's also something on non-discrimination under the school lunch because they're required by the USDA federal organization to anyone that gets for federal funding is required to publicly state and have a public facing non-discrimination statement.

[McLaughlin]: So I noticed that our school lunch department has one on their page under the USDA requirement.

[McLaughlin]: Just quickly, a sample from Newton Public Schools.

[McLaughlin]: This is a non-discrimination statement from Newton Public Schools.

[McLaughlin]: It's not necessarily an accommodation statement.

[McLaughlin]: I haven't done a deep dive into other districts to see about that.

[McLaughlin]: One of the things I liked about the Newton Public Schools non-discrimination statement is that as you can see here where I highlight,

[McLaughlin]: Newton Public Schools does not exclude from participation, deny the benefits of Newton Public Schools from or otherwise discriminate against any of these individuals.

[McLaughlin]: So, you know, that exclude from participation is part of it, deny the benefits of, you know, is another part of it.

[McLaughlin]: So they're sort of covering themselves there under

[McLaughlin]: the being more, you know, broad in terms of making sure that people aren't being excluded, although, again, there's no direct instruction on how to get accommodations or to request accommodations if your student needs to.

[McLaughlin]: Yeah, they talked about, Marblehead I liked, it talked about being proactive allies, fostering belonging and acceptance.

[McLaughlin]: And again, these are more DEI statements, I mean, more non-discrimination statements than they are active accommodation statements, but there's some sort of examples.

[McLaughlin]: But going back to the top now, and again, this document would be available.

[McLaughlin]: to all, and I would very much recommend that people look at some of these if they're so inclined.

[McLaughlin]: I also just wanted to share there was a recent Supreme Court ruling for a deaf student, which I'm sure Joan is very well aware of this.

[McLaughlin]: This was a landmark decision that just happened recently, where a student

[McLaughlin]: who was, you know, not receiving accommodations in his school district, not just related to academics, but to all activities, was able to exhaust all of his efforts, both under IDEA and ADA.

[McLaughlin]: So in some instances, IDEA, you know, it is through the Problem Resolution Service where system or

[McLaughlin]: yeah, problem resolution system, no, program quality assurance, PQA, sorry.

[McLaughlin]: But in any case, it's through that system.

[McLaughlin]: And ADA, which is the civil rights piece, is through the Office of Civil Rights in terms of people who want to, you know,

[McLaughlin]: who have a complaint and want the complaint to be explored.

[McLaughlin]: This ruling was landmark and it just happened like a month or two ago because it said that a student is not limited to one or the other, that they can actually file claims under both.

[McLaughlin]: So they can file claims under both IDEA for some of the academics, the accommodations around that and ADA, which can open districts up potentially to twice as much liability.

[McLaughlin]: And it's an important ruling

[McLaughlin]: frankly, I think all districts should know about.

[McLaughlin]: I know certainly if I was still in my policy class at the School of Ed, we would be studying this inside and out, because it's a really important decision.

[McLaughlin]: And there are a few, there are probably like a handful, maybe between five and 10 landmark decisions over the years, past 40 years, that have to do with individuals with disabilities in schools, and so they're really important, and that's one.

[McLaughlin]: Situations that make relationships sort of deteriorate in some cases.

[McLaughlin]: instances, but I would also say I've talked to families who have had experience with people who don't realize that that's the requirement and or families who don't want to ask your right because it feels like their child's a burden or it feels like they don't want to have to go through the process because it can be hard for them.

[McLaughlin]: So I think that that's a point and that's where I think the superintendent was talking about the value statement.

[McLaughlin]: you know, creating a hoax or something like that.

[McLaughlin]: In terms of how, I'm sorry, just to clarify, in terms of how it applies to

[McLaughlin]: And so I guess maybe that begs the question if you're saying that that is what is required.

[McLaughlin]: I think that according to what I saw in the DESE bullying standards, it can be a student or a staff member.

[McLaughlin]: I don't think it can be a parent or community member.

[McLaughlin]: I think you're right there.

[McLaughlin]: I think outside of the school is a different issue, although there's some gray areas around social media and that sort of thing.

[McLaughlin]: particularly with student and staff members.

[McLaughlin]: So I would agree with you that I don't think it could be a parent, caregiver, or community member, but the student and staff member, I think it can be based on what I've seen in terms of my own research on DESE and bullying.

[McLaughlin]: So I would say, yeah, includes staff members.

[McLaughlin]: Yeah, thank you.

[McLaughlin]: I think that's a really good and important point on the ADA compliance and it's something that

[McLaughlin]: The city overall needs to really consider because we have lots of ADA noncompliance in our city.

[McLaughlin]: And particularly we're concerned about some of the schools, particularly access to the schools, curb cuts, all sorts of things that disabled parking, all sorts of things that are issues.

[McLaughlin]: So we do have a disability sort of ADA committee at the school level where we're talking about some of these things and really trying to get some things in motion.

[McLaughlin]: The more people that can coalesce around this issue, the better, because as you all know, the more voices, the more people listen, and this is a really important cause across the city.

[McLaughlin]: I see far too many people that are not able to access our city, and if we want equity, we really need to ensure access.

[McLaughlin]: Thanks.

[McLaughlin]: I also just wanted to mention the intersectionality, right, of aging and disability, right?

[McLaughlin]: And so you heard Senator Jalen say, maybe we'll all be lucky enough to get older someday.

[McLaughlin]: And with that getting older, usually comes disability.

[McLaughlin]: And so getting back to the ADA point, when we're talking about

[McLaughlin]: you know, accessibility, it is elderly, it is individuals with disabilities, it's across the city.

[McLaughlin]: And some things are about money and some things are about priorities, but some things are also legislated.

[McLaughlin]: So the Americans with Disabilities Act is a law that requires access when reasonable, when reasonable accommodation.

[McLaughlin]: So really thinking about how people are coalescing around this, what civic engagement folks can get involved in, whether it's the Disability Commission, whether it's reaching out to us all here,

[McLaughlin]: creating groups to talk about how do we move these things forward because we can sit here for two hours and talk about all of this, or we can work together to get some things done and really creating, to Matt's point, some strategies around, okay, what are our goals this year?

[McLaughlin]: We're not going to tackle it all at once.

[McLaughlin]: What are our goals this year?

[McLaughlin]: Can we pick two goals this year that we want to get done?

[McLaughlin]: Okay, who wants to work on those two goals?

[McLaughlin]: So certainly, one of the things I want to work on is accessibility in the city.

[McLaughlin]: So if there's anybody here that wants to work on that, sign me up, I'm working with you, and I think it's a really important cause.

[McLaughlin]: I think it's about really civic engagement, too.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you, Superintendent.

[McLaughlin]: And I was just going to add, if folks will spread the word that, you know, we need folks here in Medford.

[McLaughlin]: And also, if there are folks here that are interested, there's positions for paraprofessionals, there's positions for substitutes, people that might want to just pick up a little extra work, you know, and get into our schools and see what's going on.

[McLaughlin]: We need you.

[McLaughlin]: That's awesome.

[McLaughlin]: Teachers in special education, so if you know young people who are looking for guaranteed positions when they're gonna get out of school, let them know that that's a field to really consider.

[McLaughlin]: Also, teacher for the visually impaired, TVI, they're almost impossible to find.

[McLaughlin]: So really specialist teachers too are really a great career to consider.

[McLaughlin]: Yeah, thank you, Jenny.

[McLaughlin]: and you cut a bigger piece off for somebody else, then somebody else gets a smaller piece, right?

[McLaughlin]: And so we have to think about that.

[McLaughlin]: What are our priorities?

[McLaughlin]: Help another workforce that has been underpaid for quite some time and we want to be able to increase the rates for everybody But again, if you're only given so much you can only do so much So it's really, you know thinking about what our priorities are and our budget shows what our priorities are Yeah

[McLaughlin]: I think in general, a lot of our community are that are not English speaking as a primary language, perhaps don't understand the function of the school committee don't understand how it operates don't understand any of those things.

[McLaughlin]: where they are opportunities to have a discussion on a topical, whether it's how to get engaged with your schools, how to ask question and answers of your school committee, what is a school committee, how do you affect policy change if needed, any of those topics.

[McLaughlin]: That's certainly one option.

[McLaughlin]: I mean, I just was at a conference on Saturday and did a presentation that was a simultaneous interpretation in Vietnamese.

[McLaughlin]: And so you can either do simultaneous interpretation where you stop and pause, or you can have the breakout rooms, like you said.

[McLaughlin]: Even with the breakout rooms, you don't have to have administration in each of the breakout rooms.

[McLaughlin]: You can actually have people listening in their language and the main meeting still happening.

[McLaughlin]: and so that there are people listening in their language, but the main meeting is still happening.

[McLaughlin]: Yeah, and so then we're still all part of the same meeting, because what I don't want is, no, I don't want people to go in other rooms with one administrator and talk, because that is sort of defeating the purpose.

[McLaughlin]: And I do think that, especially now when we know that there are so many behavioral health and social emotional needs in our community and with our adolescents, it's so important to be able to get outside of ourselves and think about how we can help other people and just that reward of helping others and helps us get outside of ourselves.

[McLaughlin]: And I wonder, is this book available to the public?

[McLaughlin]: Is it online at all?

[McLaughlin]: Yeah, that would be great because I just wanted to share you know one of the projects the English learner give back program.

[McLaughlin]: I was looking through to see what was being done with students with disabilities and English and you know students who have English as a second language or families that have English as a second language in the first

[McLaughlin]: Page 19, the first two things I saw from 2019-2020 was the English Learner Give Back program and the reverse inclusion experience that had been happening with the access classroom at the high school, which I know several of those students that participated in, and for both the students with and without disabilities, that was such a rewarding program.

[McLaughlin]: And for the EL Give Back program, these videos introducing people to the district, students to the district, and the videos are uploaded in English, Portuguese, Spanish, Haitian Creole, Arabic, Mandarin, Vietnamese, and this year, Hindi will be added.

[McLaughlin]: So I just think that that's a great example of the equity that we're talking about in the district and wanting to have this outreach in the district.

[McLaughlin]: So I applaud all of you students and all of the advisors that are out there working so hard on this as well.

[McLaughlin]: And I would ask,

[McLaughlin]: And I know that I'm hoping to meet at some point as well.

[McLaughlin]: I would ask if there can be some consideration or if there has been some consideration just in terms of outreach, what that might look like for students who are newcomers to participate in the program, right?

[McLaughlin]: Not just to be a beneficiary of the program, but to participate in the program.

[McLaughlin]: And so that might look like needing an interpreter or needing translation for some of the stuff.

[McLaughlin]: And the same goes for students with

[McLaughlin]: significant disabilities being able to participate and what that looks like for our staff to either have support, whether it be through paraprofessionals or behavior support individuals to help them be part of CCSR as well.

[McLaughlin]: So is that something that can be considered for the future?

[McLaughlin]: I couldn't agree more.

[McLaughlin]: And I love that the social justice piece is so embedded in this.

[McLaughlin]: And I just wanted to add that sometimes you need a partner to participate in the program.

[McLaughlin]: And sometimes it can be hard for some students who maybe are a little bit more isolated and don't know how to find a partner.

[McLaughlin]: So I love your peer-to-peer model because I think students get it better than any of us in terms of what that can feel like, that isolation and the need to have a mentor and what that looks like.

[McLaughlin]: So I really appreciate the thought around that.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: I'm sorry, I didn't hear what you said.

[McLaughlin]: You learned what?

[McLaughlin]: Yes, exactly.

[McLaughlin]: And so also just thinking about restorative justice, right?

[McLaughlin]: We're talking all the time about restorative justice in our district.

[McLaughlin]: And I think this is a really great example of how restorative justice can work and how, you know, again, we can get outside of ourselves and think about how we can help our community.

[McLaughlin]: Definitely.

[McLaughlin]: Member McLaughlin?

[McLaughlin]: Yeah, I also just wanted to say thank you to all the students and to let you know that the school committee is here as well for any help or outreach or anything like that that you need.

[McLaughlin]: Yes, please.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: I guess I just wanted to add, you know, to that, that, you know, I think the process is gonna be much improved, obviously, now that we have, you know, clear indicators and that there's some specificity and that the indicators can be linked to, you know, both quantitative and qualitative data that the superintendent will provide the narrative and the hard data around that as well.

[McLaughlin]: And I think that this is a really important point to point out.

[McLaughlin]: This is why professional development for school committee is really important.

[McLaughlin]: And that we understand that so that people aren't just sort of building the plane as it's flying and that we know that, you know, there's a process.

[McLaughlin]: And so having had this MASC, you know, course on superintendent evaluation and having us all sit together and do some of that professional development was really important.

[McLaughlin]: And I think really helped define a lot of this for us.

[McLaughlin]: So I guess I just want to sort of put that out there too, that as we're also thinking about our own goals and our own evaluations of stuff.

[McLaughlin]: that we're realizing and recognizing that this is an important piece that we have to have professional development for us as well, so that we're understanding, you know, what the indicators are, what the process is, what it should look like and how it can be communicated both to us and to the community.

[McLaughlin]: And then, you know, with that said, I also wanna just add, since we're on the topic of instructional, you know,

[McLaughlin]: monitoring or evaluation or guidance or what have you, that I want to make sure that really encourage people to be thinking about all of our students and all of our student learners and in that we're providing material that is, you know, the scope of all the students.

[McLaughlin]: So we're talking about, you know, some of our different classroom settings across standard

[McLaughlin]: access, you know, AP, EL, that we are really looking at the entirety of the instructional rounds and what the data is that's being collected so that, you know, we're getting those answers from all perspectives because I really obviously am interested in curriculum levels, access to curriculum, differentiated instruction for all of our students.

[McLaughlin]: So I think that would be great.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: Yeah, just point of information, thank you.

[McLaughlin]: For the Ice Cream Social, the early part of that event is sensory friendly.

[McLaughlin]: I think it was 3.15 they were doing the early end.

[McLaughlin]: Okay.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you for the work on this, Dr. Robinson.

[McLaughlin]: I have a couple of questions.

[McLaughlin]: I know that you said this is

[McLaughlin]: proposed for nine to 12 to encourage communication via phone or in person for important dialogue from the key eight community.

[McLaughlin]: And I think that the real reason for wanting this incident report in the first place was really about encouraging communication across the board.

[McLaughlin]: While I understand that the form that is being proposed may not be

[McLaughlin]: appropriate or applicable necessarily for K-8 although I have to say we certainly have heard of K-8 suspensions among other things so I wonder about that.

[McLaughlin]: I'm wondering if there's a proposal for a K-8 form.

[McLaughlin]: My concern primarily is that families are not finding out about these incidents

[McLaughlin]: after the fact or worse after several facts, which has historically been the case.

[McLaughlin]: And so that's one issue or question I have is so how are we addressing the K-8 issue and making sure that families are made aware of any incidents?

[McLaughlin]: I would also just like to add that I think one of the most memorable phone calls

[McLaughlin]: home I ever received as a parent was for my child doing really well.

[McLaughlin]: And I think it's really important while I know that we're creating structure around incidents that there are opportunities to let families know when children are doing really well as well so that we are building relationships because I think that's the real concern is that sort of deterioration in relationships.

[McLaughlin]: So to the school brains point, so the first question is what are we doing

[McLaughlin]: for K through eight.

[McLaughlin]: And then another question is for the school brains piece.

[McLaughlin]: So honestly, I was never a fan of school brains.

[McLaughlin]: It was something that you had to, as member Rousseau was mentioning, you had to drive there yourself.

[McLaughlin]: We weren't getting notification on.

[McLaughlin]: and we were just sort of told to go to school brains.

[McLaughlin]: There was no training on school brains, and I wonder if there's training for families on school brains at all.

[McLaughlin]: families about access to technology.

[McLaughlin]: Most students with IEPs have bullying plans in their IEP anyway, but if there could be some support around this line existing, that would be really helpful for those classrooms.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: they are written in such a way that other students are not identified for that particular family who's receiving the incident reports in their home.

[McLaughlin]: We're all heartbroken about what has happened to our children.

[McLaughlin]: over the past few months, but it has not been just the past few months.

[McLaughlin]: And there are plenty of people in the community that know that and that understand that.

[McLaughlin]: It has been years.

[McLaughlin]: There's a rise in violence.

[McLaughlin]: It's national.

[McLaughlin]: You can see it all over the country.

[McLaughlin]: It is happening particularly because of pandemic, but also because of the politicized nature of the hatred that exists in communities between polarized sides.

[McLaughlin]: And our children are often mimicking what they're seeing their adults do.

[McLaughlin]: And what I think is really important is what we've heard from city council members who are talking about finding solutions to work together, to collaborate, to change systems for all of our children, not some of our children, all of our children.

[McLaughlin]: This has been ongoing.

[McLaughlin]: We're talking about not just the past four years of this administration, meaning this particular superintendent, this has been an ongoing problem from when other people were on school committee, from when people have been around for some time.

[McLaughlin]: And I think that everybody in the community would agree with that.

[McLaughlin]: Follow the handbook.

[McLaughlin]: If it says, okay, if it says, if the handbook says.

[McLaughlin]: okay if a handbook says there's a weapon and if the handbook says there's a weapon and weapons result in expulsion if that's what the handbook says then that I assume is going to be what is going to be happening because that is what the handbook says but if there's a legal issue that we don't know about because maybe there's some presumption of innocence for something not this case I don't know I'm talking about any cases we don't know all the details nor do you so we can't just automatically and arbitrarily say this is what should happen with that kid and that's what should happen with this kid that's not how it works

[McLaughlin]: I was first learning about disability and disability advocacy.

[McLaughlin]: It was a mother who was working with a family leadership series as part of a state organization.

[McLaughlin]: She's a Medford mom.

[McLaughlin]: She had a teenage daughter at the time, who was in a wheelchair very complex medical needs and about.

[McLaughlin]: She had a birth injury, and her daughter was about 15 but had sort of the intellectual ability of a less than one year old and very physically not mobile.

[McLaughlin]: and was in Metro Public Schools, but was in a residential program because of her complex medical needs.

[McLaughlin]: But even in residential programs, our complex medically, complex children with medical needs come home, right, for holidays, vacations, summer vacations, what have you.

[McLaughlin]: This particular little girl, when she would come home with her mom, who did not have access to a vehicle, what have you, to get around as much as she wanted to, had no place to take her daughter.

[McLaughlin]: She had no playground to go to, and all her daughter wanted to do was swing.

[McLaughlin]: She loved to swing.

[McLaughlin]: And she was in a wheelchair, and there was no ability for her to swing.

[McLaughlin]: And so I knew when this project came about that I really wanted to work on it, and also that I really wanted to make sure that there was an ability for a person with a disability in a wheelchair to be able to get on a swing with their child, who really needed it.

[McLaughlin]: and you know this is probably the thing I'll be most proud of having worked on as a school committee member and I'm really so you know honored that you guys are part of this and that member Graham and everybody else in the community is part of this and I really want to know in terms of donating sign me up if you need you know I'm happy to donate whatever whatever we need to try to make this happen I think this is really critical so thank you so much.

[McLaughlin]: And then just one last thing there was what was the other one that was the 68.5% to six out of eight.

[McLaughlin]: The other one was the six out of eight, which was the indicators five and six, which is my indicator cheat sheet.

[McLaughlin]: Five and six are educational environments and preschool environment, right?

[McLaughlin]: Correct.

[McLaughlin]: So educational environment or percentage of children with IEPs, five and six served inside regular class, 80% or more inside regular class, less than 40%.

[McLaughlin]: So it's the inclusion rate.

[McLaughlin]: Correct.

[McLaughlin]: Yeah, yeah, I see the criteria.

[McLaughlin]: Yeah.

[McLaughlin]: So is that saying that there's room for improvement

[McLaughlin]: on our inclusion data?

[McLaughlin]: Absolutely.

[McLaughlin]: that are vulnerable.

[McLaughlin]: So I would prefer, you know, that we're talking about vulnerable as opposed to neediest.

[McLaughlin]: When are we doing suspensions?

[McLaughlin]: We, you know, had said under certain circumstances.

[McLaughlin]: So there's a lot of ambiguity around some of the policy as well.

[McLaughlin]: But I think that this is an important report and I am reluctant to delay further, but I'd like to hear from the rest of the committee.

[McLaughlin]: where elementary experience was not the same as today's standards.

[McLaughlin]: There's more action needed to bridge gaps because of the pandemic that existed both before the pandemic and certainly were exacerbated through the pandemic.

[McLaughlin]: The K-12 health curriculum needs to be a significant focus in the next year.

[McLaughlin]: It's not implemented consistently.

[McLaughlin]: and pandemic-related gaps are not closed.

[McLaughlin]: The elementary curriculum is not up to par, and the current curriculum does not adequately reflect focus on all the aspects of health expected from a modern, comprehensive health curriculum.

[McLaughlin]: So again, not just focusing on the MCAS testing curriculum levels, but across all instructional levels.

[McLaughlin]: And I'm wondering if I might have a second for my, thank you.

[McLaughlin]: Yeah, well, I guess it's more, not a question, but a clarification for the point of information is that- It's a point of clarification.

[McLaughlin]: Yeah, a point of clarification where you are asking specifically

[McLaughlin]: I am asking specifically that the policy for disciplinary referrals and incident reports allow for parental notification.

[McLaughlin]: So we can, I think it's our job to find out what the current policy is that exists in both our online policy and rules and policy handbook, as well as the student handbooks and make sure that those are consistent.

[McLaughlin]: But essentially I can speak from personal experience regarding incident reports.

[McLaughlin]: We had multiple that we were frankly unaware of until we were leaving the district and became aware of them.

[McLaughlin]: And that's not the way one wants to find out, especially when we want to support our students while they're in school.

[McLaughlin]: So the motion is specifically addressing a referral to the rules, policy and equity subcommittee to review disciplinary referrals and incident reports so that those are shared with parental notification.

[McLaughlin]: because that seems not to either be an existing policy in the current rules policy and equity listing and or some vagary in the student handbook.

[McLaughlin]: So that's my specific.

[McLaughlin]: Is that helpful?

[McLaughlin]: Mayor?

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: There's not a male approaching potentially a female and and further embarrassing them based because of all of the gender sort of

[McLaughlin]: issues or norms or what have you that exist there.

[McLaughlin]: And that I know that certainly my child or other children I would assume would prefer to be approached by potentially.

[McLaughlin]: And again, this is such a gendered conversation that it's really hard to have the conversation.

[McLaughlin]: people across gender that you might not understand that perhaps as women, we may understand some women's issues better.
