[McLaughlin]: Thank you, Dr. Edward-Vincent, for the comments.

[McLaughlin]: And I just wanted to mention at the

[McLaughlin]: CCSR project exposition today, Representative Donato was there as well, but I just wanted to highlight a couple of the projects that the students are doing, because I just do think that for folks who are listening or online, CCSR is the Center for Citizenship and Social Responsibility, and this is a group organization across the middle schools and high schools where students volunteer and they create community-based projects.

[McLaughlin]: being there today just, you know, it was so inspiring and gives me so much hope for our students and for our district to see what CCSR does and what the students bring to the table.

[McLaughlin]: There was an English language give back project where students help with interpretation for families who are English learners.

[McLaughlin]: There was a veterans recognition where they're sharing stories of veterans from the war.

[McLaughlin]: There's a stand with Ukraine where the students raised, I think, thousands of dollars to support

[McLaughlin]: folks in Ukraine, the Mystic River Cleanup, Seeds to Feed, Seeds to Feed, they built a garden with food in the quad at the school and they brought the food, the produce to one of the food pantries.

[McLaughlin]: Period Poverty, where they're helping other students who experience period poverty, the CCSR Memorial Garden to recognize those in our community who have passed during COVID.

[McLaughlin]: So much of it was just so inspiring and I just think that our students and Rich Trotter and Michael Skorka and all of the folks at CCSR that do this work should be just lauded for all of this and for the community members for next year when this happens, encourage community members to come and see these projects and see the students that are working on them because they are really inspiring and something that I think can bring us all further together.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you, Dr. Williams.

[McLaughlin]: Congratulations.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: The superintendent is not authorized to respond to City Council request to attend City Council meeting or perform any actions requested by the City Council without a majority vote of the school committee.

[McLaughlin]: I think

[McLaughlin]: I think I'm behind that, that sentence, I think that what's maybe problematic for some people is the strong wording around not authorized and I just don't know what if there's a way to wordsmith this that is a little bit more collegial, as folks were saying.

[McLaughlin]: So maybe it is the superintendent is, you know, permitted to respond to city council request.

[McLaughlin]: to attend school committee, city council meetings, perform any actions requested by the city council with a majority vote of the school committee.

[McLaughlin]: So just flipping the language, so losing not authorized and without, and making it more strength-based language is what I would suggest as a friendly amendment.

[McLaughlin]: It's very difficult to read.

[McLaughlin]: And particularly if the policy, I mean, the rules are gonna be in a, I would assume, an easy to read Google doc that the policy could be in a similar sort of format just so that they're not, because they do relate to each other, they're interconnected.

[McLaughlin]: and so that the format is similar.

[McLaughlin]: So I would just make a friendly amendment that the policy document is updated to a similar format as the rules document so that they are user-friendly for constituents and candidates.

[McLaughlin]: Can I make a point of information?

[McLaughlin]: And how they access the voucher program, particularly when we're talking about grandfathering in people, right?

[McLaughlin]: So I would be really reluctant to vote yes on, you know, ending this right now and having the current folks grandfathered in because I want to give people the opportunity to be grandfathered in and get these vouchers through perhaps some, you know, outreach or education to families about the availability of the vouchers.

[McLaughlin]: it's all kind of ambiguous.

[McLaughlin]: And I know that the intent here is, is really on point in terms of let's get rid of the bureaucracy and the paperwork and make sure that we're getting access to our students and really being there for them.

[McLaughlin]: But in reality, at the same time, the EEC voucher, you know, is created for some reason to be able to get families, you know, access.

[McLaughlin]: So if we can create a comparable sort of system without the bureaucracy, obviously,

[McLaughlin]: I think that that's great, but we haven't yet, and so how do we how do we sort of make that bridge, I guess, is what I'm saying, so I want us to really be thoughtful before just just moving ahead, because I obviously don't want to and I know you don't want to.

[McLaughlin]: exclude folks who are economically disadvantaged.

[McLaughlin]: And I think it is a real disappointment that so many of these families qualify, but they're not actually using the budget program.

[McLaughlin]: And knowing one of the directors at the EEC, I think, you know, she would be horrified to know that that's really what's happening on the ground level.

[McLaughlin]: And I'm sure that the data bears that out for them.

[McLaughlin]: So they see that in some way, as we know, with the SNAP gap and other things, why aren't people applying?

[McLaughlin]: So

[McLaughlin]: Um, I guess I would just say, I would like to be a little bit more thoughtful and just sort of moving ahead with it.

[McLaughlin]: Although I, I, I do appreciate and understand the motive behind it.

[McLaughlin]: So I would just love to know, you know, and again, what families want.

[McLaughlin]: So, you know, whether it's a, the community engagement subcommittee or, or what, I don't know, but you know, what does the hardship application look like?

[McLaughlin]: How will it be developed and implemented with community input so that we're making sure that we're being thoughtful about this, but also really having an outreach program regarding the voucher program so that families know

[McLaughlin]: that they could be grandfathered in for the rest of their child's stay if they're in fact eligible.

[McLaughlin]: This is to my colleagues, this is really about

[McLaughlin]: keeping folks informed around the school committee's policy procedures and rules, and making sure that they're accessible on the website, accessible to the community, and accessible to new committee members and others.

[McLaughlin]: So it was essentially to be sure that we're keeping some updated record of the policies, procedures, and rules on at least a monthly basis so that the community knows what our policies, procedures, and rules are, as well as the school committee members.

[McLaughlin]: I want to make sure that the link is easy to find and that the policies in there are updated regularly.

[McLaughlin]: So when I was looking for the link the other day, I could not find it.

[McLaughlin]: I actually had to go through a link from one of our memos to be able to hyperlink to it.

[McLaughlin]: I did not see an easily accessible link on the website.

[McLaughlin]: So, and I also find obviously that the paid service from the NASC is very helpful for a lot of the policies.

[McLaughlin]: And I know there are some of these that we'll be working on both through the rules

[McLaughlin]: and Policy Subcommittee and through the committee as a whole, but I wanna make sure that they're accessible now and able to be read and up to date.

[McLaughlin]: Motion to approve.

[McLaughlin]: I was wondering if- Actually, I was just gonna see if we could speak to it first, sorry.

[McLaughlin]: May we speak to it, Mayor?

[McLaughlin]: Is that okay?

[McLaughlin]: Sorry, I just wanna make sure that everybody understands the intent of the motion as well, is that some of these things are currently happening.

[McLaughlin]: So there is an ethics training that we do online.

[McLaughlin]: There is often an MASC training.

[McLaughlin]: or there was one that I did in the first term, and I'm assuming that happens regularly for other folks.

[McLaughlin]: It's not happening in January, obviously, or even before for new members.

[McLaughlin]: But our policy, current policy also has this as policy BIA, where the school committee and superintendent will assist each new member to understand the committee's functions, policies, and procedures of the committee.

[McLaughlin]: as soon after election as possible.

[McLaughlin]: Each new member shall be given the following materials, a copy of the school committee policy manual, a copy of the open meeting law, a copy of the conflict of interest regulations, a copy of the district's budget, collective bargaining agreements and contracts, student and staff handbooks.

[McLaughlin]: So there's actually more in our policy than what is in this school committee orientation motion.

[McLaughlin]: So I would ask that we include what's in the policy in the motion as well.

[McLaughlin]: And just that ensuring that this is happening and being scheduled is what the motion is.

[McLaughlin]: So it's really just putting a schedule to the policy that currently exists for orientation of school committee members.

[McLaughlin]: And if member Hays obviously would like to speak on this, mayor, I just wanted to offer that opportunity as well.

[McLaughlin]: Mayor?

[McLaughlin]: Member McLaughlin?

[McLaughlin]: I appreciate member Graham's mentioning the need that's in here because there are several and especially as new members from the last term.

[McLaughlin]: I think we can identify with that.

[McLaughlin]: And I would say I guess my only concern with this being part of the rules committee of the whole meeting that we're having is again this body has not defined

[McLaughlin]: what they see as rules and what they see as policy.

[McLaughlin]: We have a current existing policy around making sure that the school committee orientation happens, which we just said was BIA.

[McLaughlin]: And now we're saying that this should be moved to the rules meeting to make it a rule as opposed to a policy.

[McLaughlin]: And again, to be clear around the policy manual,

[McLaughlin]: our current policy manual says that if we're gonna make a change to policy, we have to put it on our schedule as a policy change so that the community has input and that we are able to have the discussion.

[McLaughlin]: So again, I don't know the difference here.

[McLaughlin]: I'm trying to help me understand the difference you guys are understanding between rules and policy and whether we're superseding the current policy that says to have a policy change, we have to put it on the agenda, not at a committee of the whole rules meeting.

[McLaughlin]: Okay.

[McLaughlin]: I would agree with that, and we can have a conversation in the rules committee of the whole then about the policy for changing the policy after we make a rule.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: I'll rescind the motion.

[McLaughlin]: And again, since this is coauthored with member Hays, I just wanna make sure that obviously she's in agreement.

[McLaughlin]: I know we'll take a roll but I'm fine with that.

[McLaughlin]: Second.

[McLaughlin]: Aye.

[McLaughlin]: May I now?

[McLaughlin]: There was two things that I was looking at in policy around this that I just wanted to bring to my colleagues attention as well.

[McLaughlin]: And so one is, you know, the fiscal management goals policy, which is the DA.

[McLaughlin]: And the first part of the fiscal management goals policy is that we engage in thorough advanced planning with staff and community involvement in order to develop budgets and to guide expenditures so as to achieve the greatest educational returns and the greatest contributions.

[McLaughlin]: So, you know, I do feel like this is our fiscal responsibility to put a schedule forward.

[McLaughlin]: And I know that assistant superintendent Murphy was talking about a process and sort of having a different process than what we've had in the past, which is understandable as well.

[McLaughlin]: But I do think we need to be able to lay out what that process is and how we're scheduling that so that the community can be involved in knowing what that is.

[McLaughlin]: And so the original motion that was approved was, whereas Medford Public Schools has historically conducted the annual budgeting process commencing in April and concluding in June, whereas there's a substantive increase in COVID-related funding for FY2022, whereas hiring practices in many districts are finalized by March-April, be it resolved the Medford Public Schools budgeting process commence in January and conclude in March,

[McLaughlin]: with budget recommendations presented to the city council in March.

[McLaughlin]: So that was the budget.

[McLaughlin]: I mean, that was approved on 11.8 by this body.

[McLaughlin]: nuance that I wanna make sure that we're understanding is that, so a motion to rescind a previous decision that was adopted by the school committee can happen at any time other than the current meeting, which obviously would be a motion to reconsider, but there's no time limit to rescind the motion, but there is some distinction around whether any portion of the motion has been executed.

[McLaughlin]: And if the motion has already been executed or is in the process of execution, it might not be rescinded.

[McLaughlin]: So I want to know, or I would amend it to whatever the superintendent thinks is reasonable for students and families to be notified of the need for summer school due to retention.

[McLaughlin]: So the motion's on the floor.

[McLaughlin]: Just needs a second.

[McLaughlin]: The motion is that we, hold on.

[McLaughlin]: Yeah, it's on page three of the agenda.

[McLaughlin]: Sorry, I just, I'm sorry, I can't hear you.

[McLaughlin]: Oh, it's on page three of the agenda.

[McLaughlin]: So, and I'm making an amendment to remove the 45 days before the last day of school for the credit remediation to prevent retention.

[McLaughlin]: But I would add that a policy will be created to define outreach for retention.

[McLaughlin]: That's, you know, communicated to the community.

[McLaughlin]: into the school committee so that we know what that is ahead of time.

[McLaughlin]: So that, cause what part of the problem was that we were hearing, I was hearing from constituents that they were not getting this communication.

[McLaughlin]: just a policy or something that is posted and lets folks know and lets us know what the process is to let families know a student may be retained and require summer school.

[McLaughlin]: And then, Mayor, I also have a statement from the

[McLaughlin]: So if that's okay.

[McLaughlin]: Oh yeah.

[McLaughlin]: I think that it will be provided with the subcommittees will be provided with a list of its functions and duties, but I don't know by whom.

[McLaughlin]: So yeah, the names definitely, and the assignments obviously we already have through the chair, but if we want the chair to be providing a list of the subcommittee's functions and duties, I guess is what I'm asking, or somebody else, I don't know.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: Yeah, this is from

[McLaughlin]: The co-chairs of the Medford Special Education Parent Advisory Council, which is tasked through mass law to advise the district on matters pertaining to special education.

[McLaughlin]: Special Education Parent Advisory Council CPAC statement.

[McLaughlin]: We represent and advocate for Medford students with disabilities and their families.

[McLaughlin]: The CPAC has concerns about the language that is proposed regarding school subcommittee meetings, specifically on how it affects the activity of the special education subcommittee.

[McLaughlin]: CPAC has advised and advocated with the school committee for many years, a forum needed to be created for a closer collaboration between school committee and CPAC.

[McLaughlin]: a collaboration which is not optional but mandated by law per MAS statute chapter 71B section 3.

[McLaughlin]: The parent advisory council duties shall include but are not limited to advising the school committee on matters that pertain to the education and safety of students with a disability, meeting regularly with school officials to participate in the planning and development of the school committee's special education programs.

[McLaughlin]: As a result of CPAC advocacy, the special education subcommittee was created in 2018 to fulfill this requirement of CPAC advising and collaborating with the school committee.

[McLaughlin]: Back then we had a different mayor, a different superintendent, and a different school committee.

[McLaughlin]: The special education subcommittee works differently than other subcommittees because it has a different role, that of collaboration between school committee, CPAC, and the special education department.

[McLaughlin]: Part of the assignment of the special education subcommittee is a dialogue with CPAC.

[McLaughlin]: An agenda set entirely by the school committee is no longer a dialogue.

[McLaughlin]: We are concerned regarding the proposed language that, quote, the subcommittee may only need to carry out business referred to it by a majority vote of the committee.

[McLaughlin]: Subcommittees will not need to conduct business brought to the subcommittee by other means or process.

[McLaughlin]: end quote.

[McLaughlin]: By the advising nature of CPAC, our mandated role is to bring business to the attention of the school committee.

[McLaughlin]: We are concerned of a circular situation in which the subcommittee cannot meet because there is no agenda and we have no agenda because we cannot meet.

[McLaughlin]: In addition, we are concerned by the proposed language that, quote, a subcommittee will be dissolved by the committee upon completion of its assignment, or it may be dissolved by a vote of the subcommittee at any time, end quote.

[McLaughlin]: The language suggests that a subcommittee can be dissolved for any reason, even if the subcommittee's assignment might be ongoing and still relevant.

[McLaughlin]: So many of you were not part of the history of the special education subcommittee.

[McLaughlin]: CPAC is asking the members of the school committee to reemphasize and remove the commitment of collaborating with CPAC

[McLaughlin]: for the benefit of the students and families we are representing.

[McLaughlin]: We hope everyone here agrees with us on the amount of progress that has been made in the district regarding disability-related policies since we started this closer collaboration.

[McLaughlin]: The impact of this collaboration was recognized and commended by DESE in their most recent special education review.

[McLaughlin]: We're asking that you maintain the role of the special education subcommittee, which is that of a continuous dialogue and collaboration between CPAC and the school committee, not only to fulfill the requirements of the law, but also Medford's recent commitment to family engagement and family school partnership.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you, Tanya Sullivan, co-chair, Alex Lorick, co-chair.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you, Mayor.

[McLaughlin]: I think, you know, part of the discussion, too, is, you know, I guess, you know, what is policy?

[McLaughlin]: And to me, policy is organic.

[McLaughlin]: I have a master's degree in education policy and management from the Harvard Graduate School of Education, and one of the things that I learned there was that policy was participatory.

[McLaughlin]: So we get feedback from our community on how we set policy.

[McLaughlin]: That is what the subcommittees are intended for, in my opinion.

[McLaughlin]: And there are some things that have been brought to the school committee that were recommendations for policy.

[McLaughlin]: Some of them were adopted, some of them weren't.

[McLaughlin]: Specifically, one of the things that we had asked for for several years as policy was that there be a subcommittee created for special education.

[McLaughlin]: And for three years, the CPAC, of which I was the former co-chair, so full disclosure,

[McLaughlin]: had asked for a subcommittee and that was being said as policy and that wasn't.

[McLaughlin]: So this is part of the discussion is that, you know, we also have what was created through our discussions and that did not need to go to policy because it was, they were,

[McLaughlin]: curriculum matters or other matters was a disability-related curriculum was created as a result of the special education subcommittee working with community members and the director of pupil services and Susanna Campbell to create a pilot program for a disability-related curriculum much needed in our district and also something that we had recommended previously as a CPAC to the school committee.

[McLaughlin]: which was not adopted, but specifically they don't have the purview over curriculum anyway, so this was able to go that way.

[McLaughlin]: We've also, the special education subcommittee also helped create professional development, again, working with community members and

[McLaughlin]: the school.

[McLaughlin]: And that's the whole point of this.

[McLaughlin]: It's back to family and community engagement and bringing community members together with school personnel, with school committee members to have an organic discussion around what policy should actually be and what should be recommended to the school committee, as opposed to just making our own policy and passing it here among the seven members.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: I want to clarify for the record that when I was saying policy is organic, what I'm saying is the process of setting policy is organic.

[McLaughlin]: It requires community engagement and staff engagement

[McLaughlin]: and administrative staff engagement, and that's part of the process in making policy.

[McLaughlin]: We do roundtable these things to see if policy needs to be set or not set or come before the subcommittee or not.

[McLaughlin]: Our specific goals for subcommittee, our requirements are

[McLaughlin]: to approve a budget, evaluate the superintendent, and set policy.

[McLaughlin]: So some of the things that are under the setting policy are also ambiguous.

[McLaughlin]: So I also feel like when we talk about things being in black and white or this is the way it should be or shouldn't be, those are subjective conversations.

[McLaughlin]: Law is subjective.

[McLaughlin]: It depends on what your priorities are.

[McLaughlin]: in terms of subcommittee meetings.

[McLaughlin]: And for me, my priority is building community relationships and building relationships with students with disabilities and staff members that are special education staff members and others, non-special education, behavioral health, mental health, sitting together, being able to discuss what is the issues, what are the issues that need to drive policy?

[McLaughlin]: Because how do we know the issues otherwise?

[McLaughlin]: Just by getting phone calls from constituents?

[McLaughlin]: I mean, that doesn't make sense to me.

[McLaughlin]: So I don't understand that.

[McLaughlin]: And saying a member can put together a motion to ask if we can have a conversation about a specific subject that may or may not lead to policy, that doesn't make any sense to me.

[McLaughlin]: And regarding the buddy system, I mean, the buddy,

[McLaughlin]: the Best Buddies program, that's only would become before the school committee if there was a cost, a directive cost involved.

[McLaughlin]: If there was something else that did not require a cost, if there was a donation, except if it was a donation over a certain amount, obviously it would need to be, but it doesn't necessarily have to be approved by the school committee as a policy issue.

[McLaughlin]: Maybe it does, maybe elements of it do, but how do we know that unless we're talking with the Best Buddies constituents, the special education teams that may or may not want Best Buddies in their school,

[McLaughlin]: the ETLs at the school, the families of persons with disabilities.

[McLaughlin]: And when we say, oh, we don't know about what happens in subcommittees, we have subcommittee minutes that we approve.

[McLaughlin]: Every single time a subcommittee meets that we go through the minutes, read them and see what's on them.

[McLaughlin]: And whether we agree with them or not, we have an opportunity at the next meeting to say that.

[McLaughlin]: So I just feel like this is more of an organic process and not one that should be dictated by black and white because relationships and relationship building is not dictated by black and white.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you, Mayor.

[McLaughlin]: I would agree that there needs to be guidance on the subcommittees.

[McLaughlin]: When this was first proposed to the school committee, that's accurate.

[McLaughlin]: We were told initially that there would not be a subcommittee of special education because there were already so many subcommittees and many of them were defunct.

[McLaughlin]: And so there was no structure around that.

[McLaughlin]: That was the whole point, that there needed to be a special education subcommittee because there was no structure around the committees that existed in the

[McLaughlin]: in the school committee prior to that.

[McLaughlin]: And, you know, I'm looking back to the letter that the co-chairs wrote and the quote that they said, a dialogue set by the school committee is no longer a dialogue.

[McLaughlin]: And I think that's the point is that CPAC came to school committee because they wanted to have an ongoing dialogue with some members of the school committee to be able to move things forward, to have the director of pupil services participate in that process, to have family members participate in that process, to have students with disabilities

[McLaughlin]: participate in that process so they could see the process of setting policy and come to the school committee at the end of the year and bring policy forward.

[McLaughlin]: Perhaps the school committee, the CPAC meeting needs to happen at the beginning of the year and they can discuss what some of their

[McLaughlin]: interest and goals and what have you are, but then that's not a conversation.

[McLaughlin]: That's them coming forward, you know, at a podium, standing in front of folks to tell them, you know, to again, ask to be included.

[McLaughlin]: And I don't feel like this is inclusive.

[McLaughlin]: I feel like we really need to think about we later on tonight, we're having a meeting on

[McLaughlin]: like 18 pages of rules that are being proposed, this is among them.

[McLaughlin]: And I think we really need to think about how are we actually involving our community members in this process and what that is and, you know, looking at what the rules were previously, looking at what the proposed rules are, not by, you know, by

[McLaughlin]: you know, motions being moved forward, but by a collaborative process.

[McLaughlin]: So again, I mean, obviously, I would also say if people are interested in the CPAC and what their views and positions are, then, you know, they meet monthly and have all sorts of presentations.

[McLaughlin]: And, you know, part of the problem was that school committee members didn't come to those meetings.

[McLaughlin]: A few have.

[McLaughlin]: over the, in the years, but a lot of times they don't.

[McLaughlin]: And I think that's important if people really want to build relationships and build dialogue, but that hasn't happened, which is another reason that the subcommittee was created.

[McLaughlin]: So again, if I don't have the votes, I don't have the votes, but I want to go on the record as saying that I think that this is not inclusive and I do not think

[McLaughlin]: that this is engaging families at all.

[McLaughlin]: I think it's actually the opposite.

[McLaughlin]: And I think that, you know, as the CPAC letter stated, that the Department of Education and DESE actually lauded our district this year in their

[McLaughlin]: memo out to the community on what a great relationship building experience has happened with CPEX.

[McLaughlin]: Cause that's not often the case in many districts because special education and special education needs and issues are complicated.

[McLaughlin]: And there can be a lot of sort of issues with families and districts and, you know, building relationships is really how we move things forward.

[McLaughlin]: And so I don't think Desi was wrong in putting that forward.

[McLaughlin]: I think it was a good point.

[McLaughlin]: I'm concerned that this will,

[McLaughlin]: affect that relationship.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you, through the chair.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you, Member Kreatz.

[McLaughlin]: I appreciate the willingness to negotiate.

[McLaughlin]: I think that's always a good,

[McLaughlin]: a good characteristic and a colleague and a school committee member and other politicians.

[McLaughlin]: And I think negotiation is a really important part of the process.

[McLaughlin]: And I think, you know, I question whether all or nothing is in fact, again, a collaborative process.

[McLaughlin]: So I'm certainly open to some discussion around negotiation on the topic, but I also did want to mention that

[McLaughlin]: In addition to the CPAC relationship with the school committee and the special education department,

[McLaughlin]: and it being recognized by DESE.

[McLaughlin]: We also had people from other towns coming to meetings and commenting about the work that was happening in the district regarding special education.

[McLaughlin]: Most recently at the last CPAC meeting, which was recorded, that was on disability awareness.

[McLaughlin]: And several other towns are asking the Medford CPAC to come to their town and talk about how we work with the district and how we collaborate with the district.

[McLaughlin]: And again, I feel like we should aim to move forward and take pride in our work and look to create an environment

[McLaughlin]: when relationships can thrive.

[McLaughlin]: So I appreciate the attempt at a middle ground in negotiation.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: potentially if the discussion, you know, creates ideas for policy and that that's what's needed.

[McLaughlin]: Yeah.

[McLaughlin]: I mean, some of the things don't fall under our purview.

[McLaughlin]: Well, I don't know.

[McLaughlin]: I mean, that's the whole point we're talking about.

[McLaughlin]: It's about bringing what we need to set policy.

[McLaughlin]: You know, what we would bring to the school committee is asking requests for setting policy.

[McLaughlin]: So what I hear you saying now is that we have the discussion and then we have to come back to the school committee and say, was our discussion okay?

[McLaughlin]: Can we further that discussion regarding policy?

[McLaughlin]: And again, I don't know.

[McLaughlin]: I know the director of people's services is here and I guess I would love to know what their position is because I know that

[McLaughlin]: They had been meeting for a month at a time, specifically the subcommittee, specifically because they had been building traction around some issues, particularly disability awareness that had been a five-year project that was finally getting some traction.

[McLaughlin]: And I wouldn't disagree that a monthly schedule can be a little bit taxing on folks, especially like last year when every subcommittee suddenly had a monthly schedule for

[McLaughlin]: reasons that are so unclear to me.

[McLaughlin]: And so there were, you know, three, four or five meetings a week in addition to our own meetings, which was really tricky, but, you know, through the chair and the superintendent, if the director of people's services would be willing to share what the experience has been with the subcommittee and whether that's been beneficial to the district or whether it's too time consuming or what have you, I know that we'd love to hear from administration as well.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: So they're- Yes, that was actually a point of information.

[McLaughlin]: That was a follow-up I wanted to have.

[McLaughlin]: I didn't think we were getting to the names of the subcommittees yet or the description, I mean, the division of the subcommittees, but I'm also unclear on some of the divisions of the subcommittee.

[McLaughlin]: But I mean, I think

[McLaughlin]: It is interesting just even as a school committee member not realizing like again the Boston 25 piece and the in the press release out to the community around this particular project and so I guess, first I would say, you know, maybe it is breaking down what are the methods of communication now, you know, what do families, potentially feel like is working or isn't working so you know I hate to say, you know,

[McLaughlin]: another a survey or whatever around that but sort of I guess maybe thinking about what is the method of communication now and that could be something that we're looking at and maybe saving examples of the communication that's going on and what that looks like and then you know certainly I'm willing to invite people for the next subcommittee meeting to share their experience around how they're getting information and what's useful and I think you know one of the things that I keep hearing from the community

[McLaughlin]: This subcommittee was started a few years ago at the request of the Special Education Parent Advisory Council.

[McLaughlin]: Our co-chairs here are here tonight for the Medford Special Ed Parent Advisory Council, Tonya Sullivan, hi Tonya, and Alex Lorick.

[McLaughlin]: And again, the subcommittee was started a few years ago with their request in mind to be active participate

[McLaughlin]: participants in special education concerns and problems of practice to work towards collaborating on policy.

[McLaughlin]: We're glad to have them here tonight.

[McLaughlin]: Our format last year, we had tried during the pandemic to split the meeting.

[McLaughlin]: The committee was renamed or reconstituted as the Special Education Behavioral Health Subcommittee.

[McLaughlin]: Last year, we were trying to do

[McLaughlin]: meetings that were divided between those two topics.

[McLaughlin]: And we've decided, based on our meeting last month, we decided to consider a new format for this year, where we are having every other topical meeting.

[McLaughlin]: So in other words, the current meeting is special education, next month meeting will be specific to behavioral health, and then we'll

[McLaughlin]: stagger each month, every other month for meetings, and that the feeling was that that would give us time in between the meetings to actively work on some of the issues and or concerns that were raised.

[McLaughlin]: And so in our last meeting, I can share the screen, my screen, and pull up our minutes from the last meeting.

[McLaughlin]: Can you guys see my screen?

[McLaughlin]: Yes.

[McLaughlin]: Yes.

[McLaughlin]: Okay.

[McLaughlin]: And so generally we came to that weren't a lot there was not a lot of participation at that meeting so I just want to go here to highlight sort of what we had been talking about as what we'll look at is the the special education proposed

[McLaughlin]: of practice to work on, and then I would like to put the proposed problem of practice out for discussion for the subcommittee to see if there's anything additional folks want to add or something altogether different.

[McLaughlin]: But essentially it was identifying ways in which to build community and school friendships among our students with and without disabilities, specifically through recreational programming, after school activities and sports organizations, as well as in school meaningful inclusion.

[McLaughlin]: along with developing supportive language, recommendations for best practices.

[McLaughlin]: So that last sentence sort of comes across what we're seeing in a number of these different entities, recreation, afterschool, sports organizations, is sort of not universal language and perhaps not, although well-intentioned, perhaps not the most

[McLaughlin]: thoughtful, I guess, into the disability community.

[McLaughlin]: So we want to be aware of how we can make recommendations around some of the printed language we see and maybe some of the other things.

[McLaughlin]: So I would encourage folks to just sort of, you know, unmute themselves or if it gets a little too chaotic, which I doubt, we can

[McLaughlin]: we can, you know, raise hands.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: So if I might add, we had a meeting last night with Medford Recreation to discuss adaptive and inclusive programming with Medford Recreation.

[McLaughlin]: And there was a community member there, Shanine Pelliquin, who's done a lot of work in this area, as you folks probably know, who talked about other districts and how they have worked with recreation departments and summer fun camps to sort of integrate all of these aspects.

[McLaughlin]: the students are actually receiving ESY services at the summer fun camp so the kids are getting their ESY service needs met and are also getting their social emotional inclusive needs met and so that was the the basis of the discussion really around you know what what are other communities doing what does it look like how could that look here and I think what we what I heard anyway from that

[McLaughlin]: that meeting especially was that you know oftentimes even with the progress that we're making in having a recreation department and having an adaptive program at the recreation department and having an adaptive PE teacher that there's still not meaningful inclusion yet but we know that that's the goal around equity especially because there's so many limits to you know what those programs look like and for example that

[McLaughlin]: The adaptive programming host about 10 students with disabilities, you know, in one given session, because they're, they're locked out after you know they have so much enrollment.

[McLaughlin]: And so, at the same time we know that in the past, special education.

[McLaughlin]: school based special education team has been providing training and support to summer fun to ensure.

[McLaughlin]: Meaningful inclusion, they are so sort of it was it was this popcorn popcorn of ideas of what could this look like across these.

[McLaughlin]: You know issues, especially because we see the department does need training around inclusive and therapeutic.

[McLaughlin]: recreation therapeutic is different obviously that's more sort of license specific but inclusive, especially using CCSR volunteers and other volunteers, you know there's it's clear that there's certainly well intentioned.

[McLaughlin]: And I just want to recognize our subcommittee member.

[McLaughlin]: Ms.

[McLaughlin]: Stone has joined us.

[McLaughlin]: Thanks for joining, Mia.

[McLaughlin]: We're just discussing the goals for this year.

[McLaughlin]: In the past, we've worked on disability awareness and improving friendships through after school, before school, after school, sports and recreation.

[McLaughlin]: And we're identifying what the

[McLaughlin]: And what we're referring to is problem of practice that we want to work on this year as a subcommittee to move forward policy recommendations at the end of the year.

[McLaughlin]: And the other question that was mentioned, so we were just talking about the disability awareness curriculum that this group worked with Susanna Campbell on and has been received really well in the community among staff and just having some data collection around what that looks like.

[McLaughlin]: And then the other question that you had, Alex, was an update on the inclusion, meaningful inclusion in schools, which was, you know, we had been discussing last year the model that was used at the high school, which was the Common Ground Program.

[McLaughlin]: And Carla, Andre, and Michael Skorka were using that program, which was essentially a reverse inclusion model where the CCSR class was coming in, I think, monthly into the access class.

[McLaughlin]: with some specific goals.

[McLaughlin]: And I'm just wondering if Carla can update us on, I know Carla, I'm sure folks know Carla, Ms.

[McLaughlin]: Andre took a position as the adaptive PE instructor, which we're very pleased to have an adaptive PE program.

[McLaughlin]: But I'm wondering, to that point, you know, does Common Ground still exist as far as anybody knows?

[McLaughlin]: And I think one of the reasons that we had talked about as a subcommittee about, you know, the best buddy program at the middle school was that we were talking about, you know, this, and again, this is reverse inclusion, to be clear, this is not inclusion, you know, so reverse inclusion is, as we said, you know, kids without disabilities coming into a

[McLaughlin]: already subseparate classroom.

[McLaughlin]: So it's not inclusion in the community or inclusion in a general education setting.

[McLaughlin]: It's a reverse inclusion model.

[McLaughlin]: But we had talked about, you know, or we had family members who had talked about wanting to expand or see things at the middle school level.

[McLaughlin]: And so that was some of the discussion that we had had last year.

[McLaughlin]: And so I guess

[McLaughlin]: the purpose of this meeting really is to identify if that's something that we want to continue to explore as a problem of practice for this group and what that would look like, or if there's something else that folks want to focus on for a problem of practice this year.

[McLaughlin]: So just to get us back on agenda topic, I want to make sure that that's what we're discussing.

[McLaughlin]: I hear you.

[McLaughlin]: I think that if so, if we want to, oh, sorry, member Rousseau.

[McLaughlin]: Disability Awareness Curriculum.

[McLaughlin]: And we did vote on it last year.

[McLaughlin]: So nobody's changing anything.

[McLaughlin]: This was voted on last year to continue the disability awareness curriculum.

[McLaughlin]: But I think the committee recognizes that this is a subcommittee and that we bring our discussion to the committee after this meeting with our minutes.

[McLaughlin]: And then if there's items that need to be voted on, that we vote on them.

[McLaughlin]: So I don't think anybody's getting the impression that, you know, we're just moving ahead without any school committee approval, but I appreciate your concern.

[McLaughlin]: Well, I think that what we do is at the end of the year, we make policy recommendations that are voted on by the subcommittee, but it's not our position as school committee to be making, in my opinion, curriculum recommendations per se.

[McLaughlin]: That is, you know, the Director of Pupil Services and others have worked to create this disability curriculum.

[McLaughlin]: It's not up to the school committee, as far as I understand, to approve or disapprove of it.

[McLaughlin]: But we have made motions at the end of the year that our policy recommendations that we say we think that this disability awareness curriculum is appropriate and that, you know, as experts in the field of disability both as with lived experience and professional experience we make recommendations.

[McLaughlin]: Remember my stone.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: So can we have a motion to have it on the agenda?

[McLaughlin]: Oh, thank you, Superintendent for defining these goals and for focusing on equity, diversity and inclusion.

[McLaughlin]: I think this is really critical.

[McLaughlin]: I'm wondering for the monthly meetings, do they include for the MASS, do they include particularly around the inclusion piece and diversity?

[McLaughlin]: Is there diverse representation and for the inclusion aspect or have they started yet?

[McLaughlin]: Do you know?

[McLaughlin]: Wow.

[McLaughlin]: I can tell you, I took an equity session with Dr. Leigh Teitel and Dr. Darnisa Amante at the ed school three years ago.

[McLaughlin]: And they are the most fantastic

[McLaughlin]: group of people to be doing this so what an excellent opportunity for you and the other superintendents I'm super excited for you.

[McLaughlin]: Congratulations.

[McLaughlin]: That's great.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: This is a report that is from an initiative that was created last year in partnership with the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education as a family school partnership initiative, spring of 2021 so partnership with several school districts met for was chosen after we applied to the process.

[McLaughlin]: And they worked with a consultant to give us some feedback on family and community engagement.

[McLaughlin]: So I'm gonna be reading from my phone just because it's easier than the small print on this PowerPoint.

[McLaughlin]: But the initiative was again, in June, 2021, an opportunity for districts to look at the family school and community partnership fundamentals, which are available on the DESE website.

[McLaughlin]: It's about building family and community engagement

[McLaughlin]: And so there's some guiding practices that they have around family and community engagement using that partnership fundamental.

[McLaughlin]: And through the process, they created several groups in order to get some feedback on family and community engagement in Medford.

[McLaughlin]: And they had four focus groups specifically that they worked with, which were number one was family members slash caregivers.

[McLaughlin]: Number two was students grades eight to 12.

[McLaughlin]: Three was teachers and frontline staff, and four was school and district leadership.

[McLaughlin]: And they wanted to identify three priorities.

[McLaughlin]: What was working well in family and community engagement?

[McLaughlin]: What innovations did we have during the pandemic period?

[McLaughlin]: And what opportunities did we have to build upon family and community engagement?

[McLaughlin]: So the family member caregiver feedback group said that the pandemic really highlighted teamwork among teachers and family members caregivers, because of I imagine remote learning among other things, but that that dropped off substantially after the return to school.

[McLaughlin]: Family caregivers felt there was a huge benefit in knowing what their child was working on.

[McLaughlin]: They felt listened to they felt like they were partners in the process and would like to see a better approach to orienting parents to the districts initially.

[McLaughlin]: They also parent and family caregivers have strong ideas about professional development.

[McLaughlin]: and they felt that they were asked for feedback on a regular basis last year, particularly, but then felt that their feedback was dismissed and they wanted more acknowledgement of diversity in the community.

[McLaughlin]: The second subgroup, eight through 12 grade students, their feedback generally from the focus group was that they did not feel like there were positive relationships for the students.

[McLaughlin]: The students felt left out.

[McLaughlin]: They said multicultural backgrounds were not included from their perspective.

[McLaughlin]: They want teachers to reach out to their families to say when things are going well, not just when things aren't.

[McLaughlin]: They wanted to see family training on technology and they felt language translation was an issue because of the overuse of Google for a translation tool.

[McLaughlin]: They also felt there was a lack of responsiveness from feedback among family and caregivers and students.

[McLaughlin]: From the teacher group, the teachers said they felt connected with families through tools like Zoom, and they wanted more time to build relationships with families.

[McLaughlin]: They wanted to see a district-wide effort for family engagement, not through forms, but through a district-wide effort to truly engage families meaningfully.

[McLaughlin]: And they mentioned that they were actually shocked by how few families had access to computers in this past year.

[McLaughlin]: So that was something that was an innovation

[McLaughlin]: through the pandemic that they were able to learn that and develop compassion around that.

[McLaughlin]: From the leadership group, the school district leadership.

[McLaughlin]: School district leadership felt too much, there was a lot of information going out, but that it was one way information.

[McLaughlin]: They wanted relationships and two way communication.

[McLaughlin]: And they said, because of competing priorities, family partnerships often falls to the bottom of the list.

[McLaughlin]: General observation from the consultant through dusty their sort of general observation summaries was there was a lot of info going out in communication for family and community engagement, but the information is not a two way communication it's a one way communication families engage

[McLaughlin]: regarding recreation.

[McLaughlin]: There's a vocal community but limited set of voices in the community.

[McLaughlin]: Families view things with a partnership lens while schools tend to view things with an information lens.

[McLaughlin]: Data on family and community engagement is not generally shared with families and note there were not any non-English speaking family subgroups that were created.

[McLaughlin]: We had intended to do that and it did not work out in terms of scheduling and so

[McLaughlin]: We wanted to make sure that there was a note that that was not part of the engagement, which I think also speaks volumes.

[McLaughlin]: They recommended consider focusing on deepening staff district readiness and capacity for family school partnerships, especially around Fundamental Five.

[McLaughlin]: This partnership fundamentals that's available on DESE has five fundamentals and Fundamental Five is building capacity

[McLaughlin]: of staff.

[McLaughlin]: So they said they recommend that Medford Public Schools consider focusing on deepening staff slash district readiness and capacity for family school partnerships.

[McLaughlin]: They think that Fundamental Five is seeing family engagement as a core practice, not a program or an individual or one job, valuing families as assets, a culture that welcomes and responds to constructive criticism,

[McLaughlin]: providing family voice data through transparency, collaborative data use surveys, et cetera, and more systemic approaches for building partnerships with non-English speaking families.

[McLaughlin]: Those were the recommendations for the report.

[McLaughlin]: This was a really unique opportunity to partner again with DESE and this outside family and community engagement audit.

[McLaughlin]: The work can continue this year if the committee is interested in terms of moving those particularly fundamental five

[McLaughlin]: forward which was considering focusing on deepening staff district readiness and capacity for family and school partnerships, they did say that if we're not going to work on fundamental five really nothing else we do around family and community engagement is going to be effective.

[McLaughlin]: So with that said, I would like to make a motion that we continue the relationship with DESE on the family school partnership initiative so that we can do the next year's work and looking at how to really increase that capacity for staff district readiness.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: Well, part of the issue is that this is a grant-funded opportunity that was created last year.

[McLaughlin]: So when it was published in DESE, it was applied for.

[McLaughlin]: So they had to act quickly through reaching out to the community and working with the school administration to have this happen.

[McLaughlin]: The second part of this is available this year.

[McLaughlin]: It doesn't last for the next year.

[McLaughlin]: I don't know what phase three of the project would be.

[McLaughlin]: I certainly think that the family

[McLaughlin]: that the community engagement subcommittee should and could be involved.

[McLaughlin]: I believe that there was reach out from Siemens school in Maine to different subgroups some during a pandemic obviously did not respond but some did and there were certainly groups

[McLaughlin]: and engagement that were involved.

[McLaughlin]: So I would love to see the community engagement committee involved in this.

[McLaughlin]: I don't know that moving it to the committee is going to be effective in terms of moving the process forward because School in Maine and DESE are offering the opportunity this year.

[McLaughlin]: So I think that there could be a collaborative effort with DESE and School in Maine and the communications subcommittee for sure.

[McLaughlin]: I can check with Desi to confirm.

[McLaughlin]: They've been pretty open-ended so far, so I appreciate the flexibility, but I would also say that to the superintendent's point, and I can completely appreciate how stressed out we all were in this past term and during the pandemic, but I also feel that as was stated in the report, that there are so many competing priorities all the time, that family and community engagement

[McLaughlin]: is always one of the last priorities, because it's one that is often pushed back for, you know, more immediate needs, such as leaking roofs, which I can understand.

[McLaughlin]: But at the same time, until we have a district-wide sort of hearts and minds around this issue, I think that it will continue to be pushed back.

[McLaughlin]: And if we didn't see

[McLaughlin]: I think last year was real evidence of the importance of family and community engagement.

[McLaughlin]: And I felt like there were some real steps forward through the pandemic, as we talked about some of the innovation and teachers and families building relationships.

[McLaughlin]: And I would just hate to see that put on pause.

[McLaughlin]: The agenda for today's meeting is we're asking community members to join us as we determine annual goals for our special ed and behavioral health subcommittee, including proposed problem practice and how we can work together to increase meaningful family and community engagement regarding these proposed concerns.

[McLaughlin]: So folks who don't know a little about the history of the Behavioral Health and Special Education Subcommittee, we were formed three years ago, actually, after multiple requests by the Special Education Parent Advisory Council, CPAC, to school committee to ask for a subcommittee specific to special education needs and issues, as there seem to be many, and these were in multiple annual

[McLaughlin]: reports to the school committee request for the subcommittee.

[McLaughlin]: It was initially created by Aaron DiBenedetto as school committee while I was chair of CPAC.

[McLaughlin]: So that's how we originated.

[McLaughlin]: And we really decided on a problem of practice for special education was building friendships, is building friendships between students with disabilities and without disabilities in our schools and our community.

[McLaughlin]: And some of the ways that we worked on that last year is looking at

[McLaughlin]: issues concerning Medford recreation and the creation of an adaptive, I mean, an adaptive, some adaptive programming for Medford recreation and

[McLaughlin]: an adaptive PE teacher in the schools, as well as unified sports.

[McLaughlin]: So we feel like we're moving things forward a bit, which is nice.

[McLaughlin]: It's nice to see some progress.

[McLaughlin]: And then for special education, you know, the topic that we had addressed last year, problem of practice, if you will, is helping to create trauma-informed schools.

[McLaughlin]: And there was some training and professional development that

[McLaughlin]: Stacey, you were putting forward regarding that, right?

[McLaughlin]: And we had a few meetings on that.

[McLaughlin]: And then we had parents who are also mental health workers, licensed social workers in the community that participated in those meetings and had some really great ideas about engaging and involving family members.

[McLaughlin]: So I did reach out to some community members who were not able to attend tonight, but had asked that we put forward some ideas.

[McLaughlin]: And I would also just love to hear from

[McLaughlin]: maybe each of you, and maybe you could talk a little bit about the structure for the meetings for this year, how you requested that it be structured a little bit differently based on just the tight schedule everyone has under the COVID pandemic, everything that you guys are dealing with.

[McLaughlin]: So I don't know which one of you wants to begin, but maybe one of you could start to talk about the difference in planning for this year.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: Joan, yeah, so what had been originally created as a special education subcommittee with a new administration in the 2019 term.

[McLaughlin]: additional subcommittees were created and topics were merged.

[McLaughlin]: And so we became, we moved from the special education subcommittee to these two really broad topics, behavioral health and special education.

[McLaughlin]: So last year, we tried to do like an hour and a half meeting where we're splitting it 45 minutes for each topic.

[McLaughlin]: And I think

[McLaughlin]: Folks felt like that maybe was a little bit long and perhaps a little disjointed.

[McLaughlin]: So this year we will alternate between the meetings, as you said, Joan.

[McLaughlin]: I think it'll be interesting to see how that goes and where people feel that's useful.

[McLaughlin]: I think some people feel that maybe what they thought was going to be nine meetings is now suddenly four or less.

[McLaughlin]: So that seems concerning.

[McLaughlin]: But I think one of the things that you had mentioned was that you felt maybe we could build some momentum

[McLaughlin]: on some of the topics in between some of the goals in between the meetings that gave us more time to sort of build some momentum around that.

[McLaughlin]: Yeah, Stacey, do you want to add anything?

[McLaughlin]: No, that sounds good.

[McLaughlin]: See the superintendent just during us welcome superintendent.

[McLaughlin]: It means that we're identifying something to work on together to achieve a goal.

[McLaughlin]: So it's just sort of a phrase that is used in identifying sort of items to work on to achieve some goals.

[McLaughlin]: in addition to adaptive programming.

[McLaughlin]: Just so everybody knows.

[McLaughlin]: So, you know, Joan, I'm sure you've heard people first language, right?

[McLaughlin]: You sort of heard, which for some people that's appropriate and for some people it's not.

[McLaughlin]: Some people prefer to have their diagnosis before their, you know, so for example, some people in the autism community prefer to be called autistic, but people perhaps in the Down syndrome community,

[McLaughlin]: People with autism may prefer to be called an autistic person, man, woman, what have you.

[McLaughlin]: And people, for example, in the Down syndrome community may prefer not to have Down syndrome kid first, have a child with Down syndrome or something.

[McLaughlin]: recreation staff and what have you around like what is and isn't appropriate language.

[McLaughlin]: And, you know, I look to people with disabilities themselves to really drive that conversation.

[McLaughlin]: And so I would want to include self-advocates in that conversation and really be able to understand what does that mean.

[McLaughlin]: And so I think just in all of our language, in our school, you know, in our community and in our school brochures, but also in our, on our websites, on our, you know,

[McLaughlin]: just sort of universally sort of looking at what is appropriate language.

[McLaughlin]: So, you know, when we say integrated, what does that mean?

[McLaughlin]: And, you know, inclusive, what does that mean?

[McLaughlin]: So maybe sort of just identifying what some of these terms actually mean to us and how we define them so that we're all sort of creating a primer, if you will, on what is, you know, acceptable and appropriate language in this way.

[McLaughlin]: Because sometimes I think, and what I hear from families is that

[McLaughlin]: They see something in writing or notice something in a brochure, and it is perfectly well intended it is not meant to hurt or harm by any stretch, but sometimes you don't know what you don't know.

[McLaughlin]: you know, it can be considered, you know, painful to family members of children with disabilities and to children with disabilities themselves or people with disabilities themselves.

[McLaughlin]: So just how are we being more sensitive around some of that?

[McLaughlin]: I think that's one way to start.

[McLaughlin]: Just around, again, brochures, you know, sports brochures, you know, signups, right?

[McLaughlin]: Like when we talked before about having like, you know, some, you know,

[McLaughlin]: quote in the signups, for example, that we all know Medford public schools doesn't discriminate based on, you know, race, you know, ability, all those things, but what does that language really look like?

[McLaughlin]: And how do we vet that as the special education subcommittee and make recommendations to the school committee so that this is universal language that's used across the districts and, you know, something that hopefully the city will adapt as well.

[McLaughlin]: So we had several folks who came on board and who wanted to offer support services around like how can we support the schools as professionals, not that we would have, you know, people come in and, you know,

[McLaughlin]: you know, volunteer in a professional capacity, but they bring professional expertise to the table.

[McLaughlin]: So I'm thinking, for example, Heather Rumenak, we know is a licensed mental health worker and, you know, who had identified a number of topics she felt were of concern.

[McLaughlin]: And so did it, you know, was it an annual event that we host that's sort of around awareness or, you know, was there some other way that we engage community members and especially around some of the

[McLaughlin]: behavioral health, mental health stuff.

[McLaughlin]: We also had a family that participated regularly last year and I ran into mom recently who was talking a lot about invisible disability.

[McLaughlin]: And I think mental health is often, can often be what's perceived as an invisible disability when somebody has mental health needs and they don't necessarily wear those needs on their face or have an IEP accompanying them or a 504 accompanying them, or they may, but they still don't have those identifiable factors.

[McLaughlin]: And oftentimes what can present, what can be anxiety can present as behavior.

[McLaughlin]: and can result in negative outcomes for our children in our schools and with our staff.

[McLaughlin]: And I think that that's a really interesting aspect as well to consider as a problem of practice, perhaps to explore.

[McLaughlin]: And when we say problem of practice, I think that we think about what this subcommittee can do is offer resources, some research, some ideas

[McLaughlin]: and then come together to discuss them around how to address this particular problem of practice, hopefully come to some resolution by the end of the year on a couple of recommendations to make to school committee as policy.

[McLaughlin]: Maybe that's one of the, you know, goals that we consider is how are we actually, you know, doing the, you know, the outreach around the Department of School Counseling, right?

[McLaughlin]: And sort of how are we letting families know?

[McLaughlin]: backpacks or are they going to home with students that like our school adjustment Councilors have specifically worked with?

[McLaughlin]: And I just wanted to add, if I could quickly, the Medford Recreation, we're actually, again, this is part of the Behavioral Health Special Education Subcommittee work because community is part of the life of the school and community for our students.

[McLaughlin]: And so we are establishing a meeting with Medford Recreation and the mayor, currently scheduled for November 17th at 5.30 p.m.

[McLaughlin]: If you can join us, it's gonna be likely via Zoom and or in-person or hybrid.

[McLaughlin]: If you wanna join us, that would be great to have families there.

[McLaughlin]: We are advocating for additional funding for Medford Recreation to have more inclusive integrative programming, because right now they have pretty much two adaptive classes and about 20 or so other classes.

[McLaughlin]: And the reality is with the Americans with Disabilities Act, students with disabilities are of course entitled to go to any of the classes and there should be supports across all of them.

[McLaughlin]: And the adaptive program is really wonderful and great.

[McLaughlin]: And we want to make sure that that is highlighted.

[McLaughlin]: But you know, we also want to make sure that we're not creating subseparate programming, which further divides our kids instead of being integrated or inclusive, or integrated and inclusive and unified.

[McLaughlin]: So that's part of the work we'll be doing with the mayor November 17.

[McLaughlin]: We have a meeting with Metro rec several families are already coming if you'd like to come please email me and

[McLaughlin]: we can talk again about how we're moving this work forward.

[McLaughlin]: But I think the exciting thing, and I don't want people to lose sight of the fact that it's happening, right?

[McLaughlin]: How long have we been wanting this and looking for it?

[McLaughlin]: And it's happening now, right?

[McLaughlin]: We have adaptive programming.

[McLaughlin]: We have a rec department, first of all.

[McLaughlin]: Now we have adaptive programming.

[McLaughlin]: And we'll get to inclusive and integrated.

[McLaughlin]: And we have the unified sports and adaptive PE.

[McLaughlin]: And this is the first year for that.

[McLaughlin]: And it just means it's gonna grow and get better.

[McLaughlin]: So I'm excited about the change that's afoot.

[McLaughlin]: Super exciting.

[McLaughlin]: And Carla, I guess I just want to add one of the things that I used to be really sort of against like adaptive stuff, because I wanted Gracie to be able to just be able to be with the other kids.

[McLaughlin]: And I thought, you know, she has the right to be with the other kids.

[McLaughlin]: And of course she does.

[McLaughlin]: But she also deserves the scaffolding and the supports to be able to teach her how to do that.

[McLaughlin]: And that's really a big piece of adaptive PE and adaptive programming.

[McLaughlin]: And Shanine Peliquin, who used to be with EMARC, now Communitas, and is a community member in Medford and works really hard towards inclusion.

[McLaughlin]: was the person that really helped me understand that, that adaptive is about building a bridge to be able to support kids in the community in all kinds of settings.

[McLaughlin]: So I think it's really great to be able to look at it that way.

[McLaughlin]: And- I know, I've been scarred for life over dodge ball, Jamil, so I can totally identify with Courtney.

[McLaughlin]: Or having to like sweaty, try to get ready for your next class, like without taking showers, how gross that was.

[McLaughlin]: And then, can I just add, if you guys are going to the Unified tomorrow, I'm planning on going, if you're going, you know, take pictures, share on social media, invite your, you know,

[McLaughlin]: candidates, your representatives, your whatever people that put it out there on social media, maybe someone consider writing something for the patch or, you know, the transcript, it's really good to get the word out and to celebrate this in our community and let people really understand the pride that comes in this.

[McLaughlin]: And I'm excited to watch how the kids interact with each other tomorrow.

[McLaughlin]: And, you know, Gracie's funny, because she's like, I was telling her that we were going to go today.

[McLaughlin]: And she was like, No, no, no.

[McLaughlin]: And I said, you know, it's not today, it's tomorrow.

[McLaughlin]: And

[McLaughlin]: I'm still trying to get that concept and everything's right now, which in a way can be a good thing, being mindful, I guess, in the moment.

[McLaughlin]: But I was saying, you know, tomorrow, and then she finally agreed that she would go, but then it was like, but I wanna play.

[McLaughlin]: And I was like, you're not playing, you're watching.

[McLaughlin]: So we will see how that all goes tomorrow, but you know, I'm just gonna, you know, roll with it, take it in stride and, you know, let her enjoy and have fun.

[McLaughlin]: One of the things that I think we really need to encourage and celebrate is the beauty of imperfection among all of us.

[McLaughlin]: So I look forward to seeing you guys in whatever state tomorrow.

[McLaughlin]: That's awesome.

[McLaughlin]: And I think that that's a sign of a true leader.

[McLaughlin]: And then also I wanted to say and just share with the community you know last week we were at the middle school.

[McLaughlin]: graduation ceremony.

[McLaughlin]: And we have the privilege of being out on, in this instance, out on the field, and we're facing the audience, but the students are facing us.

[McLaughlin]: So they're back to the audience, but we have the opportunity to look at the students and watch the students during the ceremony, which is really quite remarkable as well.

[McLaughlin]: And I was so proud when you were speaking to the students, because I could see so many of the students sitting up in their seat and listening to you and really watching you.

[McLaughlin]: And I think that they've been doing that.

[McLaughlin]: some time and to have a leader such as yourself, a woman, a woman of color in this role and have our students to be able to see you and look up to you in that role I think is quite remarkable.

[McLaughlin]: So I think we're very fortunate and I want to say thank you.

[McLaughlin]: Motion to approve the evaluation.

[McLaughlin]: The Summer Fund counseling and staff were receiving training from the,

[McLaughlin]: expertise of folks in the special education department to ensure inclusive practice and best practice around both the American with Disabilities Act and also, obviously, you know, IEP supports, what have you.

[McLaughlin]: So as we're thinking about these expanded school days, these, you know, wraparound environments, the enrichment programs, I'm wondering how are we thinking about all of those programs being accessible to our students that are most vulnerable from our students who are currently enrolled in access programs to students, you know, with autism to English learners to, you know, all of the above sort of

[McLaughlin]: What is the strategic and proactive plan for making sure that we are truly being an inclusive school district?

[McLaughlin]: As I know that equity is one of our big aces in that we're looking at how our staff is receiving appropriate professional development and training to make sure that these programs are all inclusive so that all families and all students are able to access and be enrolled.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[McLaughlin]: And if I may, just as a point of privilege, may I just respond before anyone else, if I might?

[McLaughlin]: Yes, thank you.

[McLaughlin]: And I appreciate your response.

[McLaughlin]: And I guess my sort of response to that would be with effective training, right?

[McLaughlin]: So there needs to be training to make sure that

[McLaughlin]: these programs are inclusive.

[McLaughlin]: It's one thing to say we're inclusive and everybody can come, but then when you have children who need supports and you show up and their supports aren't there or staff hasn't been trained, it's not really.

[McLaughlin]: So, you know, where is this sort of effective, you know, the planned training around how to make sure that these environments are inclusive?

[McLaughlin]: And so I think to just the after school program, there's a lot of times where, you know, families are unfortunately, you know, asked to leave because there's not enough supervision for the child with a disability.

[McLaughlin]: Or I think about

[McLaughlin]: you know, the enrichment programs where the academic enrichment programs, some of these students might be, you know, seventh grade students working on a second grade level.

[McLaughlin]: So I did write down, and I'll be brief, but I have to, Tony.

[McLaughlin]: Thank you, Superintendent and Dave and the administration for including me in this, because I'm really happy to recognize your leadership, your hard work, your dedication to the staff and students of Medford School Department on the occasion of your well earned retirement.

[McLaughlin]: Six years ago, we became colleagues in protecting the health and well-being of the Medford Schools community.

[McLaughlin]: Whether it was meeting as part of the School Health Advisory Committee, implementing youth risk behavior surveys, tackling behavioral and mental health issues facing our students.

[McLaughlin]: You remember all the work on the vaping public health crisis?

[McLaughlin]: We thought that was challenging.

[McLaughlin]: Then along came COVID.

[McLaughlin]: You immediately went from being my colleague to being my partner.

[McLaughlin]: You jumped in with contact tracing and offered your staff to assist from day one.

[McLaughlin]: metric meetings, reopening plans to testing, we quickly became attached to the hip.

[McLaughlin]: Your leadership, your support, your counsel on tough positions will never be forgotten.

[McLaughlin]: Most of all, the numerous early morning meetings and late night phone calls where often I just needed a friend to vent to and you were always there and my partner became my friend.

[McLaughlin]: I can't thank you enough.

[McLaughlin]: When I was wavering, you always reeled me in and you stuck with the science and the data and the facts.

[McLaughlin]: So in closing now, I just wanna mention something that sticks out in my mind still.

[McLaughlin]: On one of many ridiculously early Saturday morning calls regarding testing results, I remember calling you while I was still in my pajamas, looking at the results coming in.

[McLaughlin]: You picked up the phone and said,

[McLaughlin]: Let me call you back in two minutes.

[McLaughlin]: I'm just checking out at the grocery store.

[McLaughlin]: I remember thinking, wow, she is amazing.

[McLaughlin]: And you are.

[McLaughlin]: Enjoy your retirement.

[McLaughlin]: You'll be great in this.

[McLaughlin]: Congratulations.

[McLaughlin]: personally because you were so gracious taking care of our little girl when she had to have a body cast in a wheelchair for two months and you and your staff with her open wounds and everything else, you just made us feel confident handing her over to you.

[McLaughlin]: And we know that you make every family feel that way.

[McLaughlin]: And that has been really special.

[McLaughlin]: So thank you so much.

[McLaughlin]: So regarding the building friendships and community,

[McLaughlin]: We've looked at a number of options and we are talking about expanding a high school program and the staff there are looking at how to work with the middle school to extend the program, which is currently a reverse inclusion model where general education students are going into

[McLaughlin]: for example, access classrooms, but having that as part of a class, as a curriculum, as opposed to every now and then occasion.

[McLaughlin]: Let's see ensure all families are welcome.

[McLaughlin]: I was happy about the collaboration.

[McLaughlin]: Oh, Munis was an example of not knowing what that was.

[McLaughlin]: So in your glossary.

[McLaughlin]: Equity whole child data cycle screenings.

[McLaughlin]: I have no idea what you're talking about.

[McLaughlin]: So screenings I can, you know, deduce data cycles.

[McLaughlin]: I'd like to know more like sort of what you mean, you know, you don't have to answer that necessarily now but

[McLaughlin]: know if you want to email me that because I want to make sure that member Graham has her questions addressed as well.

[McLaughlin]: E2 curriculum disability awareness lesson plans.

[McLaughlin]: So again around curriculum I was just thinking about I know that Susanna has been building a bank of books and adapted and modified books which is really great for access to curriculum and I'm just thinking about again there's lots of resources for lesson plans what have you.

[McLaughlin]: Racial equity, let's see, disability awareness.

[McLaughlin]: Oh yeah, so the disability awareness curriculum for the students, the pilot program for K-1 through high school.

[McLaughlin]: I guess I was a little, and I was excited about the MTSS.

[McLaughlin]: Oh, I wanted to ask, under NTSSE, do you want to include athletics in there?

[McLaughlin]: So I don't know if it would be under enrichment, but something to think about.

[McLaughlin]: group that you want to create.

[McLaughlin]: And I love, love, love

[McLaughlin]: the fact that you guys are saying we wanna create a community that sees diversity as a strength because it is our strength.

[McLaughlin]: So I think it is a huge asset for Medford and I love that you guys wanna highlight that.

[McLaughlin]: So that's my feedback.

[McLaughlin]: meeting.

[McLaughlin]: And, you know, I think some people often think of that as like, you know, just literally how much time is spent in a gen ed classroom, but it is so much more than that.

[McLaughlin]: especially under the current circumstances.

[McLaughlin]: But I'm wondering about a centralized opportunity or almost like a C-click fix, you know, sort of, or option or, you know, complaint line or something where we can collect data on what is actually happening in the community for our transportation, because we are paying a lot of money to our vendors, and I feel like there's no accountability to the vendors.

[McLaughlin]: There's no sort of consistency around what the vendors are providing, and even in some of the contracts I've seen

[McLaughlin]: Letters come home to parents saying that if you miss the bus in the morning, you're not going to get picked up in the afternoon, which is a complete violation, right?

[McLaughlin]: You can't do that.

[McLaughlin]: But this is for special education transportation, for example.

[McLaughlin]: But that was a letter that we specifically saw.

[McLaughlin]: So this is what I'm saying.

[McLaughlin]: There has to be some consistency around the contracts, around the budgets, but also around the sort of complaint process.

[McLaughlin]: Because if

[McLaughlin]: one administrator's hearing complaints on one section of it and another's hearing another, like who's centralizing these complaints for us to understand as a school committee what the bids are on these vendors and whether they're reasonable.
